two  back-to-back  subprograms.  Subprogram  1

The  Financial  Market  Regulation  and  Intermediation  Program 
(FMRIP)  is  proposed  to  be  supported  by  a  program  cluster

Subsector: Finance sector development 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, governance  
Subtheme: Financial and economic governance 
 
Category C 

 
 
The  goal  of  the  Financial  Market  Regulation  and  Intermediation 
Program  (FMRIP)  is  to  increase  the  contribution  of  the  financial 
sector to economic growth and development of the Philippines by 
promoting  a  more  efficient  financial  sector  that  can  finance 
profitable private investment projects at lower cost and risk than at 
present.  The  FMRIP  will  support  the  Government’s  financial 
sector  reform  agenda  and  development  of  capital  markets  and 
other nonbank financial services. The reform agenda is structured 
around  policy  outcomes  mostly  in  line  with  the  Government’s 
Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan (MTPDP) 2004–2010. 
 
The MTPDP is centered on targets for increased and sustainable 
growth and job creation during 2004–2010. It envisages real gross 
domestic product growth rates of 5.3%–6.3% in 2005 and 7%–8% 
by  2010,  driven  by  exports  and  investments.  To  realize  these 
targets, the Philippines requires a wide range of financial services 
and  instruments,  in  addition  to  what  can  be  provided  by  the 
banking  subsector.  Broadening  and  deepening  the  financial 
system 
enhancing 
transparency,  and  improving  market  efficiency  will  contribute  to 
economic  growth  and  development,  and  reduce  financial  sector 
vulnerabilities  and  systemic  risks.  Enhanced  stability  in  the 
financial  system,  strengthened  governance 
the  nonbank 
financial  subsector,  and  improved  efficiency  in  the  securities 
market  will  all  contribute  to  a  more  conducive  environment  for 
continued financial market development.  
 
The  policy  measures  include  a  set  of  financial  sector  reforms  to 
promote  diversification  of 
financial  channels,  and  enhance 
transparency and efficiency in intermediation. The FMRIP aims to 
(i)  enhance  financial  system  stability  through  improved  debt  and 
improved

and  more  robust  nonbank  financial  institutions;  (ii)  strengthen 
nonbank  financial  sector  governance;  and  (iii)  improve  securities 
market efficiency to contribute to improved investment confidence 
and climate. 
 
The  FMRIP  will  be  supported  by  a  cluster  of  two  subprogram 
loans,  with  subprogram  2  expected  to  be  ready  for  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  Board  consideration  approximately  18 
months  after  the  effectiveness  of  subprogram  1.  The  policy 
reforms  under  subprogram  2  are  indicative  and  the  scope  and 
schedule of subprogram 2 will be modified as necessary based on 
a  review  of  the  accomplishments  under  subprogram  1.  This  will 
provide flexibility in program design, as adjustments can be made 
on  the  basis  of  the  results  of  subprogram  1  and  changes  in  the 
external environment.  
 
The  FMRIP  aims  to  promote  a  more  diversified  set  of  financial 
markets  that  are  more  efficient  and  resilient.  This  is  to  be 
achieved,  by  the  end  of  the  second  subprogram  through  more 
liquid  markets,  in  particular  through  unlocking  the  potential  of 
securities markets by measures that (i) promote liquidity, financial 
(ii)  enhance 
deepening,  and  strengthened 
information 
through 
convergence  to  international  standards;  (iii)  develop  a  broader 
investor  base;  (iv)  reduce  systemic  risk  and  lower  transaction 
costs through improved settlement and payment systems; and (v) 
strengthen policy and regulatory capabilities to address the legal, 
regulatory,  supervision,  financial  governance,  and  enforcement 
challenges  of  a  more  open  and  integrated  (both  regionally  and 
globally)  economy  and  financial  sector.  These  objectives  will  be 
achieved  through  a  mix  of  reforms  at  various  levels,  including 
policy,  governance,  institutions,  and  operations.  The  FMRIP  is  a 
medium-term program cluster that comprises two subprograms, to 
be  provided  over  the  medium  term.  Subprogram  1  supports  the 
Government’s  financial  sector  reform  agenda,  with  a  focus  on 
development  of  capital  markets  and  other  nonbank  services. 
Subprogram 1 will aim to (i) reduce financial sector vulnerabilities 
and  increase  the  depth  and  diversity  of  financial  intermediation 
through  improved  resolution  of  banks  and  stronger  nonbank 
financial  institutions;  (ii)  strengthen  investor  confidence  with 
improved  regulation,  governance,  and  transparency;  and  (iii) 
improve  operational  efficiency  of  the  securities  market.  From  a 
market  perspective,  subprogram  1  will  cover  debt  and  equity 
markets, deposit insurance, and the insurance subsector.  
 
A loan of $200,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources will 
be provided under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility for subprogram 1. The loan will have a 15-
year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending

Economic  growth  and  job  creation  are  the  cornerstones  of  the 
MTPDP.  The  FMRIP  supports  the  Government’s  development 
agenda  and  the  development  of  a  more  efficient  financial  sector 
that encourages more personal savings and the direction of those 
savings  into  appropriate,  private  sector  investments.  The  FMRIP 
will 
financial  system, 
strengthened  governance  in  the  nonbank  financial  sector,  and 
improved efficiency in the securities market that will all contribute 
to  a  more  conducive  environment  for  continued  financial  market 
development. The policies supported by the FMRIP are expected 
to contribute to enhanced investor confidence, and stimulate both 
domestic and foreign investments.  
 
The  FMRIP  will  boost  competition  in  the  financial  sector  and 
facilitate the growth of financial intermediaries, while improving the 
efficiency of capital markets and the allocation of resources in the 
economy.  Financial  intermediaries  will  be  enabled  to  develop  a 
wider  range  of  attractive  financial  products  for  consumers,  which 
will improve the efficiency of intermediation by channeling greater 
savings into the financial system. Together with broader economic 
reforms  in  the  Philippines,  the  reform  of  the  financial  sector  will 
thus  contribute  to  productivity  growth,  employment  generation, 
and fiscal and financial sector stability.  
 

 
Risks and Assumptions  While mitigation measures have been put in place for some of the 
key  risks  anticipated  for  FMRIP  implementation,  Subprogram  1 
still  faces  some  risks.  First,  political  instability  could  negatively 
impact  the  pace  of  reform  and  the  macroeconomy.  However, 
while significant political disturbances during 2005 had an impact 
on  spreads  on  international  bonds,  domestically  the  reforms 
moved ahead albeit with a delay.  
 
Second,  exogenous  shocks  to  the  economy  will  adversely  affect 
growth  prospects  and  threaten  macroeconomic  stability.  That 
could  in  turn  lead  to  lower  confidence  among  consumers  and 
business, and reduce demand for finance and increase the focus 
on  safe  assets,  i.e.,  a  preference  by  consumers  for  savings 
deposits and investments in government debt rather than lending 
by banks. Global growth prospects remain positive. A slowdown in 
United  States  growth  appears  to  be  offset  by  the  recovery  in 
Japan  and  stronger  growth  in  Europe.  Strong  growth  in  Asia 
bodes  well  for  export  demand  with  intraregional  trade  rising.  The 
FMRIP,  in  conjunction  with  additional  reform  programs  financed 
by ADB, and the Development Policy Support Program proposed 
to  be  jointly  financed  with  the  World  Bank,  contributes  to 
sustaining  the  economy  on  an  enhanced  growth  path  while 
mitigating the risks of macroeconomic instability. The FMRIP also 
helps  to  cushion  the  economy  from  its  remaining  exposure  to 
adverse  shocks  through  its  provision  of  significant  financial 
resources on favorable terms. 
 

 

  

v  

The third risk would be delays in pursuing financial sector reforms 
in  line  with  the  Capital  Market  Development  Plan  and  MTPDP. 
While temporary setbacks may be experienced during the course 
of  the  FMRIP,  the  momentum  in  financial  sector  reforms  should 
not be lost as the alternative of not pursuing reforms would have a 
negative  effect  on  the  investment  climate,  and  consumer  and 
investor confidence. However, this risk is considered small as the 
regulatory agencies are strongly committed to reform. 
 
A  fourth  risk  is  that  some  reforms  will  be  undertaken  without 
sufficient  consideration  of  appropriate  sequencing  resulting  in 
risks being transferred to institutions and markets before they are 
able  to  acquire  adequate  capacity  for  risk  management.  The 
FMRIP  mitigates  this  risk  by  providing  program  support  and 
technical  assistance  (TA)  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  policy 
makers and regulators to address these concerns. These risks are 
in 
further  mitigated  by  a  consultative  approach  grounded 
stakeholder discussions with the private sector, government, and 
key  international  partners  such  as  the  International  Monetary 
Fund, United States Agency for International Development, World 
Bank, and others.  
 
Finally,  serious  concerns  relate  to  inadequate  standards  of 
governance  and  incidence  of  corruption.  The  Government's 
MTPDP views graft and corruption as threats to sustained growth 
and development of the country. As such the consensus is strong 
that  good  governance  and  measures  to  address  corruption  are 
needed for a successful partnership to reduce poverty. In view of 
this, support projects are to be designed to enhance governance 
and  reduce  opportunities  for  corruption.  The  thrust  will  be  to 
institute and implement regulatory and legal reforms by promoting 
the  independence  of  the  regulator,  and  separate  operator  and 
regulator  functions.  Moreover,  institutional  reforms  will  aim  to 
ensure  transparency  and  accountability;  and  to  mitigate,  if  not 
eradicate,  administrative  impropriety  of  respective  government 
agencies.  This  will  be  reinforced  by  strengthening  consolidated 
supervision  mechanisms  via  closer  cooperation  and  coordination 
among  financial  services  regulatory  agencies.  For  instance,  the 
Financial  Sector  Forum  established  in  July  2004  provides  a 
platform  for  exchanging  information  and  ideas,  and  coordinating 
regulatory and supervisory activities of the four member agencies. 
Bangko  Sentral  ng  Pilipinas  has  been  able  to  keep  pace  with

TA  will  be  provided  and  implemented  simultaneously  with  the 
FMRIP. The TA is estimated to cost $1.15 million equivalent. ADB 
will  finance  $800,000  to  be  funded  on  a  grant  basis  from  the

The TA will support the Insurance Commission, PDIC, and SEC in 
implementing key policy reforms. For the Insurance Commission, 
TA  activities  include  (i)  develop  practices  and  methodologies  to

(ii)  support  reorganization  of  the  commission  by  preparing  the

implement

The  TA  will  assist  PDIC  in  (i)  identifying  necessary  legal 
amendments  to  revise  its  resolution  methods  and  introduce 
additional instruments for more effective resolution of failed banks; 
(ii)  formulating  guidelines  for  provision  of  financial  assistance  to

assets including asset valuation, management, and disposal; and 
(iv)  preparing  a  contingency  plan  to  deal  with  failure  of  a  large

and  records  requirements  of  investment  houses  and  other

audit procedures; and (iv) enhancing the supervisory framework to 
ensure  prompt  public  disclosure  of  material  information  by  public 
companies  and 
their  officers,  directors,  and  principal 
shareholders, with respect to beneficial ownership.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
program cluster for the Financial Market Regulation and Intermediation Program (FMRIP), and 
(ii)  a  proposed  loan  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  subprogram  1  of  the  FMRIP.  The 
report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Strengthening  Regulation  and 
Governance  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority 
delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will  approve  the  TA.  The  program  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

is

The  macroeconomic  management  priority 

fiscal 
2. 
consolidation.  This  will  allow  the  budget  to  contribute  more  to  growth  and  poverty  reduction. 
Progress on reducing the deficit has emerged as the proxy  for  markets to  gauge  Government 
commitment, capacity, and credibility to deliver on its broader agenda. ADB’s country strategy 
and  program  (CSP)  2005–2007  for  the  Philippines1 proposes  significant  policy-based  support; 
however, that assistance is conditional on the budget deficit reduction program being on track, 
and sector-specific reform agendas being in place.  
 
Erosion  of  the  tax/gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  ratio  from  17%  in  1997  to  12.5%  in 
3. 
2003,  when  the  decline  was  arrested,  was  the  primary  cause  of  the  rapid  increase  in  the 
national  Government  budget  deficit/GDP  ratio  from  0.1%  in  1997  to  its  peak  of  5.3%  in  2002. 
Increasing  losses  of  nonfinancial  government-owned  and  -controlled  corporations  (GOCCs) 
during  1999–2004,  especially  in  the  power  sector,  increased  the  consolidated  public  sector 
deficit/GDP  ratio. 2  Government  access  to  official  development  assistance  for  investment 
projects was constrained due to lack of budget cover and counterpart funding. Hence, relatively 
expensive financing was sourced from international capital markets, feeding back into high debt 
service commitments—a vicious circle that needs breaking if public fiscal space is to be created 
to allow spending for economic growth and poverty reduction.  
 
4. 
While the Government’s fiscal consolidation program includes a wide range of initiatives, 
in  view  of  the  serious  impact  of  undercollection  of  revenues  on  economic  growth  and  public 
service  delivery,  the  centerpiece  comprises  broadening  the  tax  base,  adjusting  tax  rates,  and 
strengthening tax administration. With a view to front-loading initiatives to increase tax collection, 
important  steps  include  (i)  implementing  adjusted  excise  taxes  on  alcohol  and  tobacco  from 
January  2005;  (ii)  introducing  changes  to  the  value-added  tax  to  increase  coverage  from 
November 2005 and increasing the rate from 10% to 12% from February 2006.  
 
5. 
In 2005, revenue initiatives were complemented by a reduction in the aggregate deficit of 
GOCCs, reversing a negative trend for the first time since 1999. Tax revenue increased by 18% 
in 2005 compared with average annual growth of about 7.5% during 2000–2004. In addition, the 
corporate tax rate was increased from 32% to 35% over 3 years beginning in 2005. For the first 
time since 1997, in 2005 the tax/GDP ratio improved, increasing to 13.1% in 2005 from 12.4% in 
2004, while the national Government’s budget deficit/GDP ratio declined from 3.9% to 2.7%, the 
third  successive  annual  improvement.  The  national  Government  debt  stock/GDP  ratio 
decreased  to  72%  in  2005  from  79%  in  2004.  The  outcomes  both  encouraged  and  benefited

from  more  favorable  market  sentiment:  foreign  direct  investment  almost  tripled  in  2005  (albeit 
from  a  low  base);  two  of  the  three  major  credit-rating  agencies  upgraded  their  outlooks  from 
negative to stable; sovereign borrowing costs fell,3 and the peso appreciated against the dollar 
in  the  early  part  of  the  year.  In  turn,  these  translated  to  significant  debt  service  savings—an 
important part of the emergence during 2005 of a virtuous circle, in which staying the course of 
reforms  generated  improved  market  sentiment,  which  in  turn  generated  more  favorable 
conditions for achieving macroeconomic targets.  

During  the  Philippine  Development  Forum  in  March  2006,  the  development  partners 
6. 
characterized  progress  on  aggregate  fiscal  consolidation  as  impressive  and  assessed  the 
program  to  be  broadly  on  track. 4  The  emerging  trend  is  better  than  projected  in  the 
Government’s  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  2004–2010  (MTPDP), 5  and  the 
target for achieving a balanced budget was advanced from 2010 to 2008. While ambitious, the 
development  partners  consider  this  achievable.  For  2006,  the  enhanced  value-added  tax 
revenues  are  expected  to  yield  the  equivalent  of  1.2%  of  GDP,  while  the  overall  tax  effort  is 
expected  to  improve  by  1.4  percentage  points,  from  13.1%  in  2005  to  14.5%  in  2006.  The 
national Government and consolidated public sector budget deficits are expected to decline to 
2.1% and 2.2% of GDP; 1.8 and 2.7 percentage points lower than in 2004.  

7. 
The CSP sets fiscal triggers for policy-based lending (Table 1). During 2005–2007, the 
primary trigger is a reduction of the projected Government deficit/GDP ratio of 0.7 percentage 
points (footnote 1, Appendix 8) relative to the 2004 baseline. Further, the CSP requires “actions 
to achieve the expected reduction in the deficit/GDP ratio will precede ADB lending operations, 
rather  than  actual  results  of  the  actions.”  (para.  62).  Importantly,  the  CSP  notes  that,  during 
fiscal consolidation, ADB will provide program support to help implement the budgetary, power, 
and  related  reforms  as  long  as  the  transition  remains  on  track  (footnote  1,  para.  49).  Thus,  a 
virtuous  circle  of  reform  progress  and  new  support  is  set  up:  progress elicits  new  lending  and 
new lending strengthens reforms.

III. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

8. 
ADB’s  CSP  (footnote  1)  as  well  as  the  Government’s  MTPDP,  prioritize  the  need  to 
address  fundamental  weaknesses  in  the  investment  climate  by  promoting  development  of  a 
more  efficient  financial  sector  that  can  finance  profitable  private  investment  projects  at  lower 
cost and risk than at present. Increased financial intermediation between savers and investors 
supported  by  strengthened  regulation  and  supervision  are  needed  to  increase  the  sector’s 
contribution  to  economic  growth.  Policy  measures  to  promote  diversification  of  financial 
channels,  enhance  financial  governance  and  market  efficiency,  and  reduce  systemic  risks  will 
contribute to increased investment confidence and a stronger investment climate.  
  
A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

Shallow and Narrow. At an M2 to GDP ratio of 62% at the end of 2004,6 financial sector 
9. 
development  in  the  Philippines  is  the  third  lowest  in  Asia  after  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic  and  Cambodia,  and  far  behind  regional  competitors  such  as  Malaysia  and  Thailand, 
which have financial depth ratios of more than 100%. Government issuances dominate the debt 
market, while the domestic equities market remains small compared with other Asian countries. 
The  resulting  inadequate  intermediation  between  savers  and  investors  has  slowed  Philippine 
economic growth and development. However, an effective and efficient financial sector can only 
be  created  over  the  longer  term  through  difficult  governance  reforms  in  regulation  and 
supervision combined with structural diversification of financial channels to promote competition, 
improved private sector governance, and enhanced resilience. A sector analysis is provided in 
Appendix 2. 
 
10. 
High  Concentration  of  Banking  Institutions.  The  financial  sector  is  dominated  by 
banks,  accounting  for  more  than  80%  of  sector  assets.  According  to  the  compilation  of  the 
central  bank,  Bangko  Sentral  ng  Pilipinas  (BSP),  at  the  end  of  2005  banking  assets  totaled 
P4,456.50  billion.  This  high  concentration  in  banking  institutions  is  understated  as  most 
nonbank  financial  intermediation  is  done  by  subsidiaries  of  large  commercial  banks.  The 
Philippines weathered the Asian crisis comparatively well. The nonperforming asset (NPA) ratio 
has been gradually falling from 18.06% at the end of June 2002 to 9% by the end of March 2006. 
Correspondingly,  the  nonperforming  loan  (NPL)  ratio  decreased  from  about  16.7%  in  2002  to 
about  7.36%  at  end  of  March  2006.  These  numbers  are  encouraging  but  are  also  somewhat 
overstated as impaired assets or assets on which banks have foreclosed are not included in the 
NPA  ratio.  The  Special  Purpose  Vehicle  (SPV)  Act  provided  fiscal  incentives  for  resolution  of 
NPAs;  about  a  fifth  of  the  NPAs  were  disposed  of  under  the  SPV  framework.  Given  the 
reduction  of  NPAs  since  2002,  in  April  2006  the  Republic  Act  9343  extended  the  deadline  for 
establishing  an  SPV  from  19  September  2004  to  18 months  from  effectiveness  of  the 
amendatory law. The act also allows the extension of the SPV transaction deadline for another 
2 years to continue strengthening banks’ balance sheets.  
 
11. 
Financing of Government Deficits. The substantial number of NPAs has inhibited new 
lending, resulting in liquidity of the banking system. The loan to deposit ratio of banks stood at 
72.5% at the end of 2005, substantially lower than the average of about 90%, which is regarded 
as normal or healthy. The liquidity has been primarily invested in readily available Government 
securities given the large budget deficits. The large deficits and their financing by banks crowd 
out the financing needs of the private sector. In addition, bank exposure to the Government is a 

                                                 
6   The  M2  to  GDP  ratio  (that  is  demand,  savings,  and  time  deposits  or  M2,  divided  by  the  output  of  goods  and 

services, namely GDP) is a common measure of financial depth. 

 

 4 

 

new  vulnerability  that  hopefully  will  be  manageable  as  fiscal  consolidation  begins  to  show 
results and private sector demand for credit gradually recovers.7 
 
12. 
Inadequate  Funding  Resources  for  Deposit  Insurance.  The  Philippine  Deposit 
Insurance Corporation (PDIC) extends financial assistance to troubled and closed banks when 
deemed  necessary  to  maintain  financial  stability  or  provide  adequate  banking  services  in  a 
community. The assistance is justified if new investors and/or funds are available to recapitalize 
the  bank  and  represent  a  least-cost  solution.  However,  if  no  rehabilitation  is  found  viable,  the 
Monetary  Board  places  a  troubled  bank  under  PDIC  receivership.  By  December  2005,  PDIC 
had  440  banks  under  receivership  and  liquidation.  The  PDIC’s  Deposit  Insurance  Fund  (DIF) 
amounted  to  P47.2  billion  at  the  end  of  2005  compared  to  an  estimated  needed  level  of  P90 
billion in relation to the assessed risks in the system.  
 
13. 
Underdeveloped  Nonbank  Financial  Subsector.  The  nonbank  financial  subsector 
remains  small.  Nonbank  financial  institutions  (NBFIs)  include  financing  companies  (with  and 
without  quasi-banking  functions),  mutual  funds  (also  known  as  investment  companies), 
insurance companies, pension funds, securities brokers and dealers, pawnshops, and pre-need 
plan companies. About half of nonbank financial assets are with pension funds and one quarter 
with the insurance industry. 
 
The  insurance  subsector  has  32  life  insurance  companies  and  104  nonlife  insurance 
14. 
companies.  One  reason  for  the  large  number  of  companies  is  the  capital  requirement  of  P50 
million,  about  $1  million,  which  is  very  low  by  regional  standards.  The  capital  requirement  in 
Indonesia  is  about  $11  million  equivalent,  $7  million  equivalent  in  Thailand  and  $5  million 
equivalent in Viet Nam. In addition, the subsector is highly concentrated with the three largest 
life insurance companies accounting for about 60% of assets and premium income. Insurance 
companies  are  major  investors  in  local  government  securities  and  equities.  Despite  the  large 
number  of  insurance  companies,  the  insurance  premium  income  to  GDP  only  ranged  from 
1.27% to 1.30% during the 3 years, 2002–2004. 
 
15. 
Among  the  collective  investment  vehicles,  mutual  funds  and  pre-need  plan  companies 
are  constrained  by  the  absence  of  a  supportive  policy  and  regulatory  framework  that  will 
adequately  protect  investors  and  provide  a  more  conducive  environment  for  both  industries  to 
grow. Under the Securities Regulation Code (SRC), pre-need plans are regulated as a security 
through  a  rules-based  (as  opposed  to  a  legislative-based)  framework.  Thus  more  sustainable 
reforms  for  both  the  pre-need  and  mutual  fund  subsector  depend  on  putting  in  place  a 
comprehensive legal and modern regulatory framework. Although relevant bills were submitted 
by the executive branch to Congress, neither adoption of a new pre-need code nor amendment 
of the Investment Company Act seems to be a priority. 

16.  Weak  Governance  and  Regulatory  Regime.  The  fixed-income  securities  market 
should  be  an  active  competitor  to  the  banks  in  the  provision  of  external  debt  for  corporations. 
However  the  fixed-income  market  is  still  dominated  by  Government  issuance,  accounting  for 
over  98%  of  total  outstanding  domestic  debt  securities.  Short-term  debt  securities,  mostly 
treasury bills, account for almost 30% of the market; and corporate issuers less than 2%. The 
commercial paper market provides an alternative source of short-term debt (up to 3 years) but it 
is  also  small.  Philippine  companies  meet  the  majority  of  their  financing  requirements  from 
                                                 
7  Banks’ principal liabilities—short-term deposits in both local and foreign currencies—are not best hedged through 
medium-term  government  debt  on  the  asset  side.  The  issuance  of  dollar-denominated  Republic  of  Philippines 
bonds has compounded the banks’ vulnerability as they are large holders of these bonds (imperfectly matched on 
the liability side by their foreign currency deposit units). 

  

 

5 

investment  management  companies, 

internally  generated  funds.  As  analyzed  in  the  Private  Sector  Assessment  of  the  Philippines8 
reasons  for  the  underdevelopment  of  the  financial  sector  include  the  concentrated  nature  of 
banking  and  the  propensity  of  banks  to  channel  funding  to  their  preferred  and  often  related 
customers,  weak  bank  and  corporate  governance,  ineffective  insolvency  regime,  and  weak 
implementation of the regulatory regime. 
 
17. 
Shallow  Equity  Market.  The  equity  market  remains  small  with  237  listed  firms  at  the 
Philippine  Stock  Exchange  (PSE)  and  a  market  capitalization  of  P5,908  billion  as  of  31 
December  2005  (equivalent  to  41%  of  GDP).  This  is  slightly  higher  than  Indonesia  but  lower 
than  Thailand  (68%  of  GDP)  and  Malaysia  (150%  of  GDP).  In  terms  of  performance,  market 
capitalization  increased  by  24%  in  2005  and  the  index  rose  by  26.4%.  However,  turnover 
velocity  (annual  turnover  divided  by  market  capitalization)  remains  low  at  14.3%  in  2004 
compared with 33.8% in Malaysia, 44.9 % in Indonesia, and 110.8% in Thailand.  
 
18. 
Coordination  in  Supervision. BSP, Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and 
Insurance  Commission  are  the  supervisory  bodies  for  banks,  nonbanks,  and  insurance 
companies. In addition PDIC has examination powers for banks that it may exercise only with 
prior  approval  of  BSP’s  Monetary  Board.  The  Cooperative  Development  Authority  regulates 
financial  cooperatives  and  the  Department  of  Trade  and  Industry  regulates  small  lending 
investors.  The  nonbank  financial  subsector  comprises  PSE  and  a  variety  of  financial 
intermediaries  including  investment  houses,  finance  companies,  broker-dealers  firms,  mutual 
funds, 
insurance  companies,  and  pre-need  plan 
companies.  BSP  also  regulates  and  supervises  NBFIs  that  are  subsidiaries  of  commercial 
banks  and  those  with  a  quasi-banking  license,  trust  operations,  and  pawnshops.  SEC  also 
serves  as  a  registrar  of  companies,  both  publicly  and  privately  held.  In  July  2004,  BSP, 
Insurance Commission, PDIC, and SEC, formed the Financial Sector Forum. The forum serves 
as  a  venue  for  adopting  a  more  consolidated  approach  to  efforts  to  enhance  the  financial 
system reform agenda, particularly in addressing harmonization and coordination of supervisory 
and  regulatory  methods  and  policies,  reporting  and  information  exchange  and  dissemination, 
and consumer protection and education. However, regulatory overlaps continue. 
 
19. 
The  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan.  The  MTPDP  (footnote  5) 
emphasizes  economic  growth  and  job  creation  as  key  to  poverty  reduction,  and  builds  on  the 
Government’s  10-point  agenda.  Real  GDP  growth  rate  targets  are  5.3%–6.3%  in  2005, 
increasing to 7%–8% by 2010. Increasing exports and higher investments are expected to drive 
growth.  While  the  MTPDP  encompasses  policies  and  actions  in  several  sectors  it  notes  the 
importance of developing the financial system to mobilize domestic savings to support growth. 
Further reforms, in particular in the nonbank financial subsector, are needed to achieve effective 
intermediation.  The  MTPDP  points  out  the  need  to  undertake  reforms  for  financial  deepening 
and outlines key reforms to be undertaken during 2004–2010. Anchored on the MTPDP is the 
Government’s Capital Market Development Plan (CMDP)—a blueprint developed for growth and 
expanded contributions to the Philippine economy, 2005–2010.9 The CMDP articulates a series 
of  11  strategic  objectives  intended  to  stimulate  the  growth,  efficiency,  and  competitiveness  of 
the capital market over the next 5 years. Preparation of the CMDP involved soliciting input from 
a wide range of stakeholders via public forums including workshops, the SEC website, and the 
news  media.  SEC  also  sought  input  from  the  Capital  Market  Development  Council  of  the

a. 

1. 

Issues and Opportunities 

Enhance Financial System Stability  

Improve Debt and Risk Management  

Philippines, an important policy body comprised of relevant policy makers from the public sector. 
On 20 October 2006, the Department of Finance (DOF) approved the CMDP. 
 
B.  
 
 
 
 
 
The Philippines has grappled with high budget deficits since the Asian crisis. Revenues 
20. 
to  GDP  are  low  averaging  about  14.5%  since  2001,  with  tax  revenues  equivalent  to  about 
12.5% of GDP. The reasons for the low ratio of tax revenues are inefficient tax collection and 
perceived tax evasion. Persistent budget deficits have led to high borrowing requirements, and 
subsequent  buildup  of  debts,  domestic  and  foreign.  The  weak  fiscal  environment,  inflationary 
pressures, and policy uncertainty contributed to high borrowing costs. In 2004 the Government 
adopted  measures  to  increase  revenues  and  prepared  stringent  budgets  aimed  at  fiscal 
consolidation.  
 
21. 
Debt  management  is  a  joint  responsibility  of  BSP,  Department  of  Budget  and 
Management,  DOF,  and  National  Economic  Development  Authority.  The  Bureau  of  Treasury 
(BTr) under DOF has a central role as it issues debt securities, manages borrowed funds, and is 
responsible for cash management for the Government. Programming, structuring, and timing of 
government  borrowings  is  undertaken  jointly  with  BSP  and  Department  of  Budget  and 
Management. Domestic debt consists of short-term treasury bills and bonds. Treasury bills are 
for 91 days, 182 days, or 364 days. The bonds have a tenor of 2, 5, 7, 10, or 20 years. Treasury 
bills are auctioned every Monday and treasury bonds every second and fourth Tuesday. Thirty-
three  primary  dealers  are  licensed  to  take  part  in  the  auctions.  The  auction  process  is 
automated  and  settlement  is  T+2.  BTr  operates  the  Registry  of  Scripless  Securities,  the 
depository  for  government  debt  securities.  Trading  in  the  secondary  market  takes  place  over-
the-counter (OTC) by licensed dealers. BTr is also responsible for issuing international bonds. 
The  annual  borrowing  target  is  communicated  to  the  markets;  while  the  timing,  size  for 
individual issues, and currency composition are determined separately. Total public sector debt 
to GDP was 105% in September 2005; 72% was national Government debt. Of the Government 
debt, 55% was domestic and 45% foreign, with the ratio gradually changing in favor of domestic 
debt.  Short-term  debt  made  up  16%  of  total  domestic  and  foreign  debt,  but  30%  of  domestic 
debt.  Public  sector  debt  has  increased  through  a  buildup  of  contingent  liabilities,  especially 
through Government guarantees on debt to GOCC debt, in particular in the power sector.  
 
22. 
BTr is not in charge of the Government’s contingent liabilities such as debts incurred by 
GOCCs,  guarantees  issued  to  private  sector  partnerships  such  as  build-operate-transfer 
projects,  and  guarantees  for  loans  to  GOCCs.  These  corporations  are  managed  by  the 
Corporate Affairs Group in DOF, while the Bureau of Local Government Finance is responsible 
for  monitoring  local  government  unit  borrowing.  Thus  several  agencies  are  involved  in 
monitoring  various  aspects  of  public  sector  borrowing.  While  the  Development  Budget 
Coordinating  Council10 is  involved  in  government  borrowing  as  part  of  the  fiscal  program,  the 
management  of  debt  and  contingent  liabilities  is  not  effective.  The  high  debt  and  contingent 
liabilities  call  for  enhanced  efforts  for  coordination,  monitoring,  and  management.  Sound  debt 
and  risk  management  will  increase  investor  confidence  and  bring  about  a  more  conducive 
environment for investment. 
                                                 
10 The  council  consists  of  BSP,  Department  of  Budget  and  Management,  DOF,  National  Economic  Development 

Authority, and Office of the President.

b. 

Improve  Resolution  of  Banks 
Intermediation 

and  Strengthen  Financial 

institutional  arrangements  can  be  used 

 
23. 
NPA  Resolution.  High  numbers  of  NPAs  affect  the  lending  behavior  of  banks  and  in 
turn can have adverse impacts on the systemic stability of the industry. Banks are deterred from 
lending  by  the  need  to  provide  capital  for  NPAs,  and  instead  seek  safer  profit-making 
opportunities by purchasing government debt. As a result, intermediation suffers. Managing the 
nonperforming assets that the state decides to take off the books of problem banks is central to 
bank  restructuring  efforts.  To  the  extent  that  bank  problems  can  be  traced  to  relatively  well-
defined chunks of NPAs, banks can be strengthened if these assets are taken off their books. 
While  various 
for  asset  management,  asset 
management  companies  or  reconstruction  companies,  or  distinct  loan  workout  units  have 
played  an  important  role  in  resolving  systemic  banking  difficulties  and could  be  considered  as 
part  of  best  practice.  Asset  management  companies  have  typically  been  Government-initiated 
and owned. Much will depend on the extent of Government intervention in restructuring in terms 
of creating enabling provisions to facilitate the process. Countries such as Indonesia, Republic 
of Korea, Malaysia, and Thailand set up centralized asset management companies.  
 
24. 
Philippines  banks  were  largely  spared  from  the  1997  banking  crisis  due  to  the  high 
prudential limits put in place by BSP prior to the breakout of the crisis. Only when NPAs started 
to rise to uncomfortable levels in 2000 did the Government decide to introduce a law enabling 
speedy  disposition  of  distressed  assets.  In  view  of  its  high  fiscal  deficits,  the  Government 
decided  to  pass  on  the  task  of  relieving  banks  of  their  distressed  assets  to  the  private  sector 
through the passage of the Republic Act 9182, better known as the SPV Act (para. 10). The law 
provides  guidelines  for  the  establishment  of  asset  management  companies  and  provides 
incentives on a number of taxes, such as the documentary stamp tax and capital gains.  
 
25. 
As  the  banking  industry  prepares  for  the  adoption  of  pillar  3  of  the  Basel  II  risk-based 
capital framework (para. 27), BSP is encouraging banks to prioritize NPA cleanup to avoid steep 
capital  charges.  With  or  without  the  SPV  extension,  bank  asset  cleanup  remains  crucial  in 
restoring the supply of credit to the economy. 
 
Financial  Safety  Net.  Against  the  backdrop  of  the  changing  financial  landscape  and 
26. 
financial innovation driven by liberalization and improving technologies, a financial safety net is 
needed  to  maintain  the  stability  of  the  financial  system  and  avert  any  financial  crisis.  Well-
functioning  deposit  insurance  reduces  the  possibility  of  a  banking  crisis.  Bank  runs  are  costly 
because they interfere with the financial intermediation performed by banks. Financial intermediation 
in  a  continuously  changing  financial  environment  can  be  complex  and  difficult.  PDIC  is  central  to 
systemic  stability  in  the  Philippines  through  its  role  in  the  resolution  of  failed  banks.  PDIC, 
governed by a charter (amended in 2004) provides legal indemnification for PDIC officers, and 
raised  deposit  insurance  coverage  from  P100,000  to  P250,000  without  a  corresponding 
increase in the assessment rates that form the basis for the DIF. A key consideration in designing 
a pricing scheme for a deposit insurance system involves the choice of an assessment base. With 
currently more than 440 banks in receivership and the risk of many more needing assistance, 
the  DIF  is  less  than  the  estimated  adequate  funds  needed  in  relation  to  risks  in  the  banking 
system.  Equally  important  is  developing  the  capacity  or  techniques  to  resolve  failed  institutions. 
PDIC’s resolution methods are comparatively limited. The agency can purchase assets from a 
problem bank, provide low-interest loans, or assume liabilities. PDIC cannot, however, purchase 
voting  or  common  stock.  Furthermore,  limited  staff  resources  and  existing  rules  contribute  to 
cumbersome and ineffective processes for asset valuation, management, and disposal. 
 

 

 8 

 

 

2. 

c. 

Strengthen Nonbank Financial Institutions 

Strengthen Nonbank Financial Subsector Governance 

 
 
27. 
Risk-based capital adequacy (RBCA) is the international norm for banks in accordance 
with the Basel Core Principles for Banking Supervision. The new framework, commonly referred 
to as Basel II, is due to come into effect in 2007. The use of RBCA is being extended to NBFIs 
in  contrast  to  using  only  a  minimum  or  net  capital  requirement.  SEC  followed  the  RBCA 
approach in 2004 by issuing a RBCA rule for broker dealers for implementation starting in 2005. 
Broker  dealers  were  the  starting  point  for  SEC  to  introduce  RBCA  for  NBFIs.  Insurance 
companies  are  only  subject  to  minimum  capital  requirements,  which  are  very  low  by  regional 
comparison.  These  requirements  are  deemed  inadequate  in  relation  to  the  scope  of  business 
and risks inherent in insurance. 
 
 
 
28. 
SEC is tasked with regulating as well as  developing capital markets. Previously, policy 
reforms  in  the  nonbank  financial  subsector  were  influenced  by  events  in  the  market  and 
responses  to  events  rather  than  by  a  long-term  vision  for  the  subsector  and  its  role  in  the 
economy. Such a vision and plan would aim to ensure a sound legal and regulatory framework 
to  enhance  governance  and  form  the  general  framework  and  key  parameters  necessary  for 
subsector  development.  One  milestone  in  financial  sector  development  was  reached  in  2000 
when  the  SRC  was  enacted,  providing  an  updated  legal  framework  for  the  securities  market. 
The SRC needs to be supplemented by a range of reforms to enable the capital markets to take 
a larger role in financial intermediation. 
 
29.  Market  Development.  Most  importantly,  in  view  of  the  challenges,  the  sector  needs  a 
vision of financial market development and strong leadership to guide policy actions to achieve 
that vision. While many Southeast Asian economies (e.g., Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and 
Viet  Nam)  have  master  plans  or  blueprints  for  financial  sector  or  capital  market  development, 
the Philippines has lagged. Thus, while the SRC of 2000 provided a sound basis for regulation 
of  capital  markets,  it  did  not  explicitly  clarify  SEC’s  role  in  promoting  market  development  or 
address the corresponding implications for SEC’s organizational and regulatory posture. This is 
a crucial gap in the current context.  
 
30. 
In addressing challenges and formulating the agenda to be supported by the FMRIP, the 
Government  formally  adopted  objectives  for  capital  markets  through  the  CMDP.11 The  CMDP 
provides a medium-term context (2005–2010) to set goals and milestones against the backdrop 
of  financial  innovation  and  regional  and  global  financial  sector  integration,  while  providing  the 
means to assess progress toward their attainment. 
 
31. 
Transparency  and  Disclosure.  Accounting  and  auditing  standards  that  provide 
accurate  information  of  companies’  financial  soundness  are  critical  elements  for  governance 
and transparency. Globally, international accounting standards (IAS) and international financial 
reporting  standards  (IFRS)  developed  by  the  International  Accounting  Standards  Board  are 
being adopted. The Philippines accounting standards have been modeled on the United States 
generally  accepted  accounting  principles.  However,  in  2005  the  Philippine  Accounting 

                                                 
11  The  CMDP  was  developed  under  ADB.  2003.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of 
Directors  on  a  Proposed  Loan  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Second  Nonbank  Financial  Governance 
Program.  Manila.  The  CMDP  originally  covered  the  nonbank  financial  sector  but  based  on  the  need  for  key 
legislation  to  address  key  impediments  to  the  development  of  investment  companies,  pre-need  companies,  and 
insurance companies, which is outside the control of the executive branch, the decision was made to focus only on 
the capital market. 

  

 

9 

Standards  Council  resolved  to  adopt  IAS  and  IFRS  to  bring  Philippine  standards  in  line  with 
international best practice. For the financial sector, IAS 39, with provisions for mark-to-market of 
assets, is of particular importance in providing accurate valuation of investment portfolios. The 
Philippines is also moving to full adoption of international auditing standards developed by the 
International Federation of Accountants. 
 
32. 
Insurance.  The  insurance  subsector  is  governed  by  the  outdated  Insurance  Code 
(1974), which needs to be modernized to enable the Insurance Commission to fully carry out its 
mandate  by  giving  it  sufficient  power  to  enforce  the  law  and  regulations.  The  commission  is 
currently hampered, as compared to other regulators, as that it is not independent, is bound by 
the  salary  standardization  law,  and  has  an  unwieldy  organizational  structure.  Implementing 
regulations  build  on  the  code,  but  have  in  some  instances  been  upgraded  to  meet  current 
requirements. A self-assessment of compliance with the 28 core principles of the International 
Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) reveals that the Insurance Commission is not in full 
compliance.  
 
The  Insurance  Commission  currently  has  a  functional  organizational  structure  with 
33. 
separate  divisions  for  licensing,  financial  analysis,  etc.  However  the  absence  of  a  computer 
network  to  facilitate  the  flow  of  information  between  departments  has  resulted  in  a  lack  of 
overview and thorough analysis of individual companies. The organization’s current setup and 
inadequate business processes continue to hamper effective supervision of the industry. 
 
34. 
Anti-Money Laundering. In 2001, the Government enacted the Anti-Money Laundering 
Law and established the Anti-Money Laundering Council in BSP. The council has grown from a 
staff  of  8  to  56  in  5  years.  Work  on  anti-money  laundering  continues  to  be  strengthened  and 
implemented  with  ongoing  ADB  and  other  development  partner  support.12 As  a  result  of  the 
Government’s excellent progress in implementing anti-money laundering reforms, the Financial 
Action Task Force (FATF) removed the Philippines from the list of noncooperative countries and 
territories  in  February  2005.  In  June  2005,  the  Philippines  was  accepted  as  a  member  of  the 
Egmont  Group  (an  international  group  of  financial  intelligence  units  focused  on  facilitating 
information sharing and promoting best practices). Following the enactment of the law, BSP and 
SEC strengthened related regulations and established procedures for cooperating and reporting 
to  the  Anti-Money  Laundering  Council.  The  Insurance  Commission  followed  suit  in  November 
2005 and issued new regulations for anti-money laundering in line with the IAIS core principles 
for  regulation  of  insurance  companies;  monitoring  of  compliance  is  now  needed.  The  Anti-
Money Laundering Council needs to provide ongoing training for staff of insurance companies 
who  are  not  conversant  with  the  anti-money  laundering  law  and  regulations,  and  compliance 
with them. 
 
35.  Market  Supervision. SEC as the regulator of securities trading markets has, pursuant 
to the SRC, registered PSE as a self-regulatory organization (SRO). Pursuant to its status as an 
SRO,  PSE  is  the  primary  regulator  of  the  secondary  securities  market  and  thus  is  required  to 
effectively  undertake  market  surveillance  of  trading  activities  as  well  as  inspection  of  member 
brokerage firms to ensure compliance. The new fixed-income exchange, Philippine Dealing and 
Exchange Corporation (PDEx), recently registered as an SRO with SEC, and will initially focus 
on oversight of interdealer trading in fixed-income securities.

 10 

 

The development and sustainability of financial markets depends on compliance with the 
36. 
legal  and  regulatory  framework  to  ensure  that  markets  are  operated  fairly.  Building  credibility 
with  investors  through  policy  consistency,  effective  regulation  and  supervision,  improved 
enforcement  and  surveillance,  and  continuous  dialogue  among  various  stakeholders  is  of 
paramount importance to creating a better investment climate. 
 

3. 

Promote Securities Market Efficiency  

 
Liquidity  in  government  debt  markets  is  low.  Most  investors  appear  to  buy  and  hold 
37. 
government securities to maturity. The reasons for this are intertwined. A large number of debt 
issues  make  for  a  thin  market.  Further,  most  government  debt  is  issued  at  shorter  maturities 
and therefore few issues of long maturities are available for trading. The low turnover results in 
an inadequate yield curve, and hence no effective benchmarks. Borrowing and lending of debt 
securities and short selling would increase liquidity, but are only partially allowed.  
 
38. 
Notwithstanding the sluggish economic performance, the depth of financial markets and 
equity  market  capitalization  in  the  Philippines  exceeds  those  in  many  economies  outside  the 
region with a similar or higher per capita income. However, the size of the markets and liquidity 
in secondary markets remains low in comparison with most other Southeast Asian economies. 
Malaysia  and  Thailand,  in  particular,  have  achieved  strong  performance  in  terms  of  overall 
financial deepening as well as in growth of bond and equity markets in recent years. Against this 
background, the Philippines faces twin challenges: first, that of catching up with its neighbors; 
and second, ensuring that it is able to participate in ongoing developments leading to a greater 
integration  of  regional  markets  and  economies.  In  terms  of  the  latter,  facilitating  greater 
openness to cross-border investment in equity and bond markets will require closer attention to 
adoption  of  harmonized  or  convergent  approaches  to  financial  reporting  standards  and 
supervision  and  regulation  of  financial  markets.  This  will  be  facilitated,  and  domestic  financial 
markets will be strengthened, by strong and resolute policy action on the domestic front to bring 
standards of financial governance and regulation, supervision, and enforcement capabilities to 
international standards. 
 
39. 
Secondary  trading  in  government  bonds  has  been  exclusively  OTC,  and  bilateral  or 
privately  negotiated  with  deals  executed  by  telephone.  An  investor  can  thus  receive  different 
prices  from  different  dealers  as  the  system  has  no  efficient  price  discovery.  Complete  data  of 
secondary  trades  does  not  exist.  This  lack  of  transparency  means  that  trading  volumes, 
turnover, or depth cannot be measured.  
 
40. 
Corporate debt is dominated by commercial paper. Commercial papers range from less 
than a year to 3 years and are often held by the underwriter or a small group of investors.13 The 
secondary market in commercial paper is opaque as all trading takes place OTC and no data is 
collected  on  pricing.  Indeed  the  clearing  and  settlement  risks  to  secondary  trading  are 
increasing  causes  of  concern  and  provide  the  basis  for  measures  to  separate  custodian  and 
brokerage functions as well as for other measures directed at improving the payments system. 
 
Liquidity in the equity market is low for several reasons. One is the limited free float of 
41. 
listed  equities.14 The  relevant  rules  for  borrowing  and  lending  in  securities  are  expected  to  be 
approved  soon.  Another  liquidity  supporting  measure  is  short  selling  of  securities,  which  is 

                                                 
13  Commercial paper receives favorable tax treatment in contrast to corporate bonds. Thus, the term is often used to 

refer to medium-term debt in the Philippines in contrast to the use of this term in other capital markets.  

14  Although the PSE listing rules require listed companies to maintain a free float of 10% of outstanding capital stock, 

these rules have been suspended. 

  

 

11 

4. 

Lessons 

partially allowed under SEC rules but the current rule is insufficient for short selling to work as a 
liquidity-enhancing measure.  
 
42. 
Scripless securities have become the norm in developed markets with electronic trading, 
clearance, and settlement. PSE through its central depository uses the computerized book-entry 
system  to  transfer  ownership  of  securities  from  one  account  to  another,  thus  eliminating  the 
need for physical exchange of scrip between buyer and seller. However, a significant holding of 
securities is still in the physical form. Under the current system, the investor has the option to 
hold  on  to  the  certificate  (uplift)  or  deposit  (lodge)  this  certificate  with  the  depository.  Physical 
transfer  of  bond  certificates  is  not  permissible.  Migration  to  a  scripless  environment  for  the 
equities  market  is  desirable  to  achieve  lower  transaction  costs  for  intermediaries  and  clients, 
reduce settlement risks associated with failures for the timely delivery of securities, and facilitate 
eventual  reduction  of  the  settlement  cycle.  The  2002  E-commerce  Law  provides  the  basis  for 
legal recognition of electronic ownership. However, the current legal and regulatory framework, 
market infrastructure, and market players do not support full dematerialization. 
 
 
 
43. 
ADB  has  supported  reforms  in  the  financial  sector  for  more  than  10  years,  with  three 
program  loans  between  1995  and  2004.  These  include  (i)  Capital  Market  Development 
Program,15 (ii)  Nonbank  Financial  Governance  Program,16 and  (iii)  Second  Nonbank  Financial 
Governance  Program  (SNFGP). 17  Through  this  continuous  support  ADB  has  maintained 
ongoing  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government,  regulatory  agencies,  industry  associations,  and 
market  players.  The  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  is  the  only  other 
development partner providing consistent long-term support through extensive TA in the sector. 
ADB  and  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  consult  closely  to  ensure 
complementarity. The development coordination matrix is in Appendix 3. 
 
The  First  Program:  Laying  the  Legal  Foundation.  The  Capital  Market  Development 
44. 
Program loan was to (i) consolidate the two stock exchanges, (ii) encourage transparency and 
accountability through increased public disclosure of financial information, and (iii) build capacity 
and market confidence. The second tranche of the loan was linked to the enactment of a new 
securities  law  and  policy  actions  dependent  on  the  new  law.  Substantial  delays  in  the  legal 
process resulted in cancellation of the second tranche in December 1999.  
 
45. 
The  Second  Program:  Strengthening  the  Regulatory  Framework.  The  Capital 
Market Development Program loan laid the foundation for further reforms. The SRC, enacted in 
2000, and its implementing rules and regulations, provided the legal and regulatory framework 
to  pursue  governance  reforms  in  the  sector.  These  reforms  were  supported  by  the  Nonbank 
Financial  Governance  Program  (designed  as  a  single  tranche  loan),  which  included  (i) 
restructuring  SEC  and  strengthening  its  monitoring  and  enforcement  capacity;  (ii) modernizing 
PSE’s  governance  and  regulatory  structure;  (iii)  strengthening  market  oversight,  compliance, 
and enforcement; and (iv) facilitating diversification and innovation in corporate financing.

The  Third  Program:  Deepening  the  Nonbank  Financial  Market.  The  SNFGP, 
46. 
approved in September 2003, was to promote development of the nonbank financial subsector 
by  (i)  strengthening  the  regulatory  and  policy  framework  for  developing  viable  institutions  and 
properly 
to  strengthen  SEC’s  enforcement 
capacities, and supervisory skills and practices; (iii) improving transparency to protect investors 
from  fraud,  insolvency,  or  misconduct;  and  (iv) facilitating  mobilization  of  domestic  saving  to 
increase  supplies  of  funds  while  ensuring  investor  protection.  A  key  element  in  these  reforms 
was  the  establishment  of  the  anti-money  laundering  regime.  The  SNFGP  was  designed  as  a 
two-tranche  loan.  Government  compliance  with  the  second  tranche  reforms  were  accelerated 
and completed ahead of schedule; the second tranche was released early in November 2004. 
 
47. 
Key  Lessons.  The  key  lessons  from  these  programs  and  reinforced  in  the  program 
completion  report  for  the  SNGFP 18 is  the  need  to  avoid  making  a  program  dependent  on 
enactment  of  laws.  To  the  extent  that  legal  amendments  are  necessary,  programs  can 
effectively  support  drafting  and  advocacy,  and  enhance  the  regulatory  framework  that 
complements legislative changes. Moreover, simply changing a law or regulation will not modify 
behavior  in  the  absence  of  strong  enforcement.  Program  design  should  necessarily  focus  on 
reforms  where  commitment  is  strong  and  adequate  resources  available  for  successful 
implementation. While funding for Government agencies remains limited, key reform initiatives 
require  adequate  resources  to  strengthen  regulatory  capacity,  especially  in  the  area  of 
monitoring and enforcement. Likewise, until enforcement officials are sufficiently protected from 
frivolous and intimidating lawsuits, expecting strong enforcement actions may be unrealistic. A 
second  lesson  is  the  importance  of  stakeholder  involvement,  which  has  been  critical  to 
achieving  the  policy  reforms  supported  by  the  Nonbank  Financial  Governance  Program  and 
SNFGP. The market participants through their respective associations should be consulted and 
brought into the reform process to ensure effective implementation.  
 
48. 
These lessons are underscored by the program performance audit report for the Capital 
Market  Development  Program,  which  stresses  the  importance  of  (i)  a  medium-term  policy 
framework supported by a program cluster and tranching structure that ensures adequate time 
and  flexibility  in  formulation  and  implementation  of  a  reform  agenda;  (ii)  need  for  participatory 
dialogue and prior passage of laws; (iii) emergence of stakeholder voice and a reform champion; 
and  (iv)  design  of  TA  to  ensure  adequate  funds  are  made  available  for  a  sufficiently  long 
duration,  with  a  view  not  only  to  develop  policy  recommendations,  but  also  to  support 
implementation. The FMRIP has incorporated these lessons as well as those emerging from the 
Review  of  ADB’s  Approach  to  Conditionality.19 Thus,  the  FMRIP  has  been  framed  within  the 
context  of  a  medium-term  program  cluster  that  reflects  (i)  ADB’s  confidence  in  the 
Government’s commitment to a medium-term agenda in which it has ownership, (ii) a focus less 
on  traditional  conditionality  and  more  on  a  broad  assessment  of  progress  and  implementation 
capacity  of  the  authorities,  and  (iii)  program  design  aligned  to  assist  the  authorities  in 
implementing and operationalizing their strategy. 
 
49. 
The  impact  of  ADB  assistance  is  assessed  in  the  country  assistance  program 
evaluation, 20 which  highlights  that  in  the  aggregate  ADB’s  significant  volume  of  support  to 
Philippines during 1986–2002 did not translate to a commensurate level of intended outcomes. 
In keeping with the evaluation recommendations, CSP lending for 2005–2007 is more prioritized

50. 
The challenge now is to take up, extend, and deepen reforms initiated under the SNFGP. 
This  is  predicated  on  the  need  for  a  policy  and  institutional  response  to  the  significant  market 
developments since SNFGP completion. These include the need to underpin growth prospects 
through improved financial intermediation; respond to the regulatory and supervision challenges 
posed  by  the  demutualization  of  PSE  and  establishment  of  a  new  exchange  for  fixed-income 
instruments;  address  capital  adequacy,  market  fragmentation,  and  regulatory  capacity  in  the 
insurance subsector; facilitate enhanced risk transfer mechanisms through the promotion of new 
financial instruments such as securitized assets; and promote a greater capacity to hedge and 
manage risks in the context of regionally and globally integrated financial markets. 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

51. 
The  FMRIP  aims  to  promote  a  more  diversified  set  of  financial  markets  that  are  also 
more  efficient  and  resilient.  This  is  to  be  achieved  through  more  liquid  markets,  in  particular 
through  unlocking  the  potential  of  securities  markets  by  way  of  measures  that  (i)  promote 
liquidity,  financial  deepening,  and  strengthened  intermediaries;  (ii)  enhance  information 
reporting and disclosure standards through convergence to international standards; (iii) develop 
a  broader  investor  base;  (iv)  reduce  systemic  risk  and  lower  transactions  costs  through 
improved settlement and payment systems; and (v) strengthen policy and regulatory capabilities 
to address the legal, regulatory, supervision, financial governance, and enforcement challenges 
of a more open and integrated (both regionally and globally) economy and financial sector.  
 
52. 
These  objectives  will  be  achieved  through  a  mix  of  reforms  at  various  levels,  including 
policy, governance, institutions, and operations. From a market perspective, subprogram 1 will 
cover  debt  and  equity  markets,  deposit  insurance,  and  the  insurance  subsector.  The  policy 
reform agenda, to be financed through a program loan, is also supported by an attached TA to 
support implementation of policy reform actions. The development policy letter and policy matrix 
for the reform agenda is provided in Appendix 4. 
 
53. 
The FMRIP is being provided in the context of a difficult macroeconomic environment in 
which investors and businesses have identified key requirements to renewed investments and 
growth  as  the  following:  macroeconomic  and  policy  stability;  provision  of  infrastructure; 
improved  investment  climate  and  governance;  and  enhanced  financial markets  intermediation. 
ADB’s support package to the Government in 2006 responds to these critical needs through two 
sector programs: for power sector reform and the present program for financial market reforms, 
which are being processed in parallel. In addition, ADB, jointly with the World Bank, is proposing 
to  process  the  Development  Policy  Support  Program,  which  will  provide  an  anchor  for  sector 
reforms targeted by the Government while addressing key issues in relation to long-term fiscal 
consolidation, the investment climate, governance, and protection of social sectors.  
  
54. 
Subprogram  I  is  designed  to  be  a  single  tranche  operation,  with  a  well-defined 
framework  to  align  with  the  Government’s  CMDP  that  is  anchored  in  the  MTPDP  (Figure  1). 
Formulation  of  subprogram  was  closely  coordinated  with  various  stakeholders,  including  the 
private sector and other development partners. Consideration of subprogram 2 will depend on 
the triggers set by the CSP for 2008 (Table 1) as well as progress in (i) implementation of the 
CMDP  action  plan,  (ii)  reforms  in  the  insurance  subsector,  and  (iii)  resolution  of  banks.  This 

 

 momentum  is  needed  to  develop  the  financial  sector  in  order  to  benefit  from  integration  in 
regional and global capital markets over the medium and long term. 

 

Policy Framework and Actions 

B. 
 
55. 
The  goal  of  subprogram  1  is  to  increase  the  contribution  of  the  financial  sector  to 
economic growth, poverty reduction, and development of the Philippines by promoting a more 
efficient financial sector that can finance profitable private investment projects at lower cost and 
risk  than  at  present.  Subprogram  1  will  aim  to  (i)  reduce  financial  sector  vulnerabilities,  and 
increase the depth and diversity of financial intermediation through improved resolution of banks 
and  stronger  NBFIs;  (ii)  strengthen  investor  confidence  with  improved  regulation,  governance, 
and transparency; and (iii) improve operational efficiency of the securities market. Subprogram 
1  supports  the  Government’s  financial  sector  reform  agenda,  with  a  focus  on  development  of 
capital markets and other nonbank services. 
 
56. 
The policy measures include a set of financial sector reforms to promote diversification 
of  financial  channels,  and  enhance  transparency  and  market  efficiencies  in  intermediation. 
Diversification  when  combined  with  governance  reform  may  contribute  to  spillovers  and 
externalities  that  can  increase  the  sector’s  contribution  to  economic  growth  and  development. 
The reform agenda is structured around the following policy outcomes, which form the basis of 
three components for subprogram 1: 
 

Enhance financial system stability. 
Strengthen nonbank financial subsector governance. 
Improve overall efficiency of the securities markets.

1. 

Component 1: Enhance Financial System Stability 

a. 

Improve Debt Risk Management 

57. 
Reforms  will  reduce  financial  sector  vulnerabilities  and  reduce  systemic  risks  that  are 
central  to  promoting  financial  sector  development.  Subprogram  1  supports  the  Government’s 
efforts in improving its debt and risk management strategy in the face of large debt obligations 
and contingent liabilities to achieve macroeconomic and financial system stabilization. 
 
58. 
Debt Issuance. BTr is central to the Government’s efforts to manage Government debt. 
BTr  has  enhanced  transparency  and  predictability  by  announcing  issuance  schedules  well  in 
advance and communicating international borrowing requirements to the markets. The policy is 
to reduce foreign currency borrowing, while diversifying and borrowing in a range of currencies. 
The  Philippines  has  benefited  from  the  general  trend  among  global  investors  to  allocate  more 
funds  to  emerging  market  bonds  and  the  compression  in  spreads  for  emerging  market  debt. 
From June 2005 to May 2006, the spread of Philippine bonds declined from 478 to 140 basis 
points.  BTr  has  successfully  reduced  the  share  of  variable  debt  rate  to  below  10%  of 
international bonds and kept the interest rate of fixed-rate debt at around 6%. A concerted effort 
is  being  pursued  to  consolidate  domestic  debt.  In  February  2006,  BTr  undertook  a  debt 
exchange with the objective of reducing the series of outstanding bonds to create fewer, more 
liquid  instruments,  and  establish  benchmarks.  Various  series  of  outstanding  Government 
securities were swapped for new bonds with 3-, 5-, 7- and 10- year maturities. A total amount of 
P111 billion was exchanged.

NPA  Resolution. BSP has been diligent in implementing international best practices in 
regulation of the banking industry (total assets account for almost 80% of the total resources of

been underpinned by continuing financial reforms and the ability of BSP to proactively respond

to various challenges faced by the financial sector. One noteworthy accomplishment is the focus 
on  reducing  NPLs  in  the  banking  industry.  The  improvement  in  overall  asset  quality  has  been 
supported by progress in the disposition of the banking system’s NPAs through the SPV Act. 
 
The SPV Act sought to encourage financial institutions to dispose of NPAs, comprising 
62. 
mainly infected loans (60%) resulting from the 1997 Asian financial crisis. The law provided for 
tax  incentives  and  other  privileges  for  the  disposition  of  NPAs  that  are  recognized  as  SPV-
related  transactions.  The  industry  experienced  a  gradual  reduction  in  NPLs.  To  maintain  this 
momentum, BSP advocated the extension of the SPV Act to enable further asset cleanup. The 
aim  is  to  dispose  off  at  least  another  P100  billion  from  the  banking  system’s  inventory  of 
remaining NPAs and thereby bring the banking industry’s NPA/NPL ratios closer to the precrisis 
level.  In  April  2006,  the  Republic  Act  9343  was  signed  extending  the  deadline  for  the 
establishment  of  an  SPV  from  19  September  2004  to  18 months  from  effectiveness  of  the 
amended law. In addition, the amended law resets the deadline for availing of tax benefits from 
April  2005  to  2  years  from  the  effectiveness  of  the  new  law.  Subprogram  1  supports  the 
Government’s legislative effort to facilitate reduction of the number of NPLs and thereby ensure 
systemic banking stability.

Philippine Deposit Insurance Corporation. If necessary, PDIC will report to Congress

rate.  The  indicative  analysis  points to  a  shortfall  of  around  P50  billion  in  the  DIF  in  relation  to 
estimated risks for a time period. PDIC has likewise formulated an investment and trading policy 
to help buildup the DIF and is currently strengthening its risk management system. The Program

as  an  integral  part  of  bank  failure  resolution.  In  addition,  the  FMRIP  will  support  PDIC  in 
developing  and  adopting  new  procedures  for  provision  of  financial  assistance  to  banks  to 
ensure  judicious  exercise  of  authority  and  in  designing  a  suitable  package  at  least  cost.  A 
framework will be developed for efficient disposal of assets of closed banks and those acquired 
from  banks  with  financial  assistance.  Finally,  PDIC  will  develop  a  contingency  plan  in 
coordination with BSP for managing the failure of large banks and successive failures of smaller 
banks. 
 

 

c. 

Strengthen Nonbank Financial Institutions 

 
Risk-Based  Capital  Adequacy.  The  increasing  sophistication  of  financial  markets 
64. 
carries  high  inherent  risks  that  must  be  adequately  addressed  through  strong  regulatory  and 
supervisory regimes, as well as adequate risk management systems and tools. This component 
aims  to  reduce  financial  risks  in  the  sector  by  strengthening  the  capital  base  of  NBFIs.  The 
insurance industry has very low capital requirements and is unevenly capitalized with respect to 
risk. Many small companies have inadequate capital in relation to underwritten insurance risks. 
To  strengthen  capitalization  in  the  industry,  minimum  capitalization  requirements  for  new  life 
and  nonlife  insurance  companies  is  set  at  P1  billion,  and  at  P2  billion  for  new  reinsurance 
companies,  effective  1  July  2006.  Existing  life  and  nonlife  companies  will  be  required  to 
increase net worth to reach P100 million by 31 December 2006.  
 
65. 
In  addition  to  the  minimum  capitalization  requirement,  subprogram  1  supports  the 
introduction of RBCA to ensure that capital is adequate in relation to risks. The formula, to be 
effective from 1 August 2007, will be different for life and nonlife insurance companies, reflecting 

 

 18 

 

the different nature of life and nonlife insurance. RBCA will be calculated based on the annual 
financial statements. Insurance companies will be given 2 years to comply. 
 
66. 
The  minimum  capitalization  for  insurance  brokers  will  also  be  raised.  For  existing 
insurance  and  reinsurance  brokers,  minimum  capital  will  be  increased  to  P2  million  by  31 
December  2006,  and  then  increased  by  P2  million  each  year  to  reach  P10  million  by  31 
December  2010.  For  new  entrants  offering  either  insurance  or  reinsurance,  the  paid-up 
capitalization  is  set  at  P20  million  effective  1  July  2006.  For  new  entrants  intending  to  broker 
both  insurance  and  reinsurance  the  minimum  paid-up  capitalization  is  P50  million  effective  1 
July 2006.  
 
67.  With respect to compliance with the RBCA rules for the securities market, every broker 
dealer  covered  by  the  RBCA  rules  is  required  to  prepare  its  RBCA  report  at  the  end  of  the 
month and file it with SEC on or before the 15th of the following month. SEC is in the process of 
enhancing  its  supervisory  framework  to  ensure  compliance  with  this  requirement.  Policy

Component 2: Strengthen Nonbank Financial Subsector Governance  

 
Capital  Market  Development  Plan.  SEC will oversee reforms to enhance governance 
68. 
standards to increase investor confidence through improved transparency and supervision. To 
guide capital market development and firmly anchor the agenda with stakeholders, the CMDP 
(para.  19),  sets  forth  11  objectives  for  capital  market  development  and  defined  initiatives  for 

  

 

19 

Government agencies, key market institutions, and other key stakeholders. Other Association of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  countries  such  as  Malaysia,  Indonesia,  and  Thailand  have  all 
published capital market development plans. The CMDP will be published and disseminated as 
the guiding policy document for capital market reforms. 
 
69. 
The CMDP’s 11 strategic objectives are grouped in four sections. The first sets forth the 
Government’s support for the plan, its role in overseeing implementation, and its commitment to 
pursue  a  sound  macroeconomic  policy  environment  conducive  to  growth.  The  section  also 
discusses the need to rationalize financial sector taxes to create equal opportunities for similar 
products  and  remove  distortions  to  encourage  savings  and  investments.  The  second  section 
focuses on key capital market institutions, and strategies and reforms envisaged to accelerate 
efficiency  and  market  growth.  The  third  section  deals  with  a  series  of  legal  and  regulatory 
measures  that  regulators  need  to  adopt  to  ensure  effective  oversight  and  enforcement, 
strengthen investor protection, and align the regulatory framework with current global standards 
and  practices.  The  fourth  section  highlights  investor  education  and  corporate  governance. 
Reform initiatives under the CMDP, along with an indicative timetable that was confirmed with 
responsible  implementing  agencies,  are  set  forth  in  a  related  action  plan.  DOF  approved  the 
CMDP and SEC formally adopted the CMDP and published it on its website in October 2006. 
SEC  will  have  primary  responsibility  for  monitoring  progress  in  implementing  the  CMDP  and 
related action plan. SEC recently established an internal monitoring unit to monitor progress in 
implementation and provide regular reports (at least every 4 months) highlighting achievements 
and related implementation issues. 
 
70. 
Transparency  and  Disclosure.  The  Accounting  Standards  Council  firmly  aligned  the 
Philippine  accounting  standards  with  the  IAS  and  the  Philippine  financial  reporting  standards 
with the IFRS starting in 2005. IAS 39 is particularly important as it provides for mark-to-market 
accounting of assets and more accurate valuation of assets and capital adjustments. Alignment 
with  the  IFRS  means  financial  reporting  will  be  comparable  to  international  standards. 
Subprogram  1  supports  the  SEC  and  Insurance  Commission  move  to  requiring  financial 
institutions  under  their  respective  jurisdictions  to  comply  with  the  new  Philippine  accounting 
standards  starting  in  2005  and  Philippine  financial  reporting  standards  in  2006.  SEC  and  the 
Insurance  Commission  have  identified  the  importance  of  well-qualified  external  auditors  for 
financial  institutions,  and  started  to  accredit  external  auditors  and  publish  lists  of  accredited 
auditors. 
 
71. 
Legal  and Regulatory  Framework. To improve the legal and regulatory framework for 
the  insurance  industry,  the  Insurance  Code  needs  to  be  amended.  Critical  elements  of  the 
proposed  amendments  to  the  law  include  (i)  providing  rules  for  appointing  the  commissioner 
and deputy commissioners on a fixed-term basis and removing them, (ii) developing exemptions 
from the salary standardization law to put the Insurance Commission on par with BSP and SEC, 
(iii)  providing  the  Insurance  Commission  with  appropriate  powers  to  impose  sanctions  on 
insurance  companies  that  fail  to  comply  with  regulations,  and  (iv)  preparing  the  expected 
transfer of pre-need companies to the jurisdiction of the Insurance Commission. The draft code 
needs to be supplemented by implementing rules and regulations. Subprogram 1 supports the 
drafting and submission to DOF of an amended code. 
 
72. 
In  parallel,  the  Insurance  Commission  intends  to  bring  regulations  fully  in  line  with  the 
IAIS  28  core  principles.  The  draft  amendments  to  the  insurance  code  incorporate  principles 
relating  to  the  legal  framework.  Of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations,  only  Malaysia 
and  Singapore  have  implemented  the  28  principles,  whereas  Indonesia  is  in  the  process  of 
doing so. The FMRIP will support a strategy for full implementation of the 28 principles.

Insurance  Commission.  To  achieve  effective  supervision,  the  Insurance  Commission

analysis  to  ensure  consistent  and  thorough  analysis  of  the  companies,  and  consequent  solid 
information underpinning supervision. The proposal has been endorsed by DOF and is currently 
with the Department of Budget Management.
