to  aid  price  discovery,  on 

 
76. 
Investors,  in  particular,  institutional  investors,  need  a  wide  range  of  instruments  with 
sufficient depth and secondary market activity to effectively manage their investment portfolios. 
Improved  market  efficiency  and  liquidity  in  the  securities  market  is  predicated  on  better 
information  disclosure 
improved  clearance  and  settlement 
mechanisms to enhance efficiency and reduce transactions costs, and by the emergence of a 
broader  investor  base  looking  for  attractive  investment  vehicles.  In  view  of  the  significant 
potential for improving the scope of disclosure of material information, the enhanced accounting 
and  financial  reporting  standards  supported  by  subprogram  1  set  the  stage  for  deepening 
securities markets.  
 
77. 
Secondary Markets. The organization of the secondary market in debt securities as an 
OTC  market  has  resulted  in  poor  price  discovery,  an  inadequate  yield  curve,  and  lack  of 

 

 22 

 

effective  benchmarks.  The  establishment  of  PDEx  promotes  effective  price  discovery  and 
transparency,  which  provides  for  a more  efficient  market  and  an  active  yield  curve.  PDEx  has 
launched an interdealer negotiated dealing board. In a bid to bring more trades onto the board, 
PDEx  introduced  an  interdealer  order-driven  system  for  firm  bids  and  offer  quotes  on  an 
anonymous  basis.  The  next  steps  include  expansion  of  trading  to  qualified  investors  and  the 
retail trading markets, and preparation for listing and trading of private fixed-income securities, 
subject to SEC approval of listing and trading rules. PDEx has also signed a memorandum of 
agreement with BTr to provide PDEx with access to the Registry of Scripless Securities to allow 
for  straight-through  processing  of  secondary  trades  of  government  debt  securities.  To  support 
transparency,  BSP  has  passed  regulations  requiring  the  establishment  of  independent  third-
party  custodians,  thus  introducing  the  needed  separation  between  custodian  and  brokerage 
functions. 
 
78. 
In  parallel  with  the  development  of  PDEx,  SEC  recently  approved  a  new  rule  that 
requires all OTC trades to be reported to a centralized trade reporting facility to enhance price 
transparency. Subprogram 1 supports SEC’s efforts to improve liquidity by authorizing securities 
borrowing and lending by NBFIs under SEC’s jurisdiction.  
 
79. 
New  Financial  Instruments.  The Securitization Act of 2004 was adopted to provide a 
legal framework for securitized issues and to enable the development of the secondary market 
for asset-backed securities. The implementing rules and regulations of the act were adopted on 
25  March  2005.  Securitization  of  assets  in  particular  will  contribute  to  developing  instruments 
that  will  be  attractive  to  a  broader  class  of  investors  for  whom  these  instruments  provide 
diversification  into  a  different  form  of  investments  with  better  risk  and  return  characteristics. 
Similarly,  for  originators,  securitization  offers  a  cheaper  form  of  financing.  While  securitization 
provides  avenues  for  more  efficient  transfer  of  risks  to  capital  markets  and  NBFIs,  a 
corresponding  need  for  caution  arises  for  pursuing  development  of  complex  securitized 
transactions that involve foreign exchange and interest rate risks. The emergence of derivative 
products and different market players, and improved risk management tools will help reduce the 
risks of securitized deals.  
 
80. 
Transactions Costs. Over the medium term, improvements are needed to the securities 
market infrastructure of electronic trading platforms, clearing, settlement, and payment systems. 
The Philippines scores well regionally for its clearance and settlement system, but falls short of 
its  neighbors  in  postsettlement  risks.  The  principal  drawback  relates  to  the  efficiency  of  the 
depositary  and  transfer  infrastructure  of  the  securities,  and  to  payments  finality  of  the  cash 
segment of the system. Payment is still based on netting of the cash segment and this is hence 
not a true real-time gross payment system (it is a model 2 delivery versus payment system). By 
contrast, BSP’s large-value settlement and payment system is a genuine real-time gross system. 
Linking the securities and cash legs of the financial markets settlement and payment system to 
BSP’s  large-value  system  would  improve  the  efficiency  of  financial  markets  and  reduce 
systemic risks. It would also allow for better integration to external payment systems and hence 
facilitate regional integration. The Government is assessing the potential for reforms in this area 
through TA provided by the International Monetary Fund. Policy measures under component 3 
are summarized in Table 4.

C. 
 
81. 
The FMRIP has a number of distinct and innovative features. First, strong Government 
ownership  and  commitment  for  the  development  of  the  nonbank  financial  sector  through  the 
adoption of the CMDP  that represent a combination of economic, business as well as legal and 
regulatory  factors  that  aims  to  materially  influence  the  development  of  the  Philippines  capital 
market as an engine of economic growth for the country. 
 
82. 
Second,  FMRIP  emphasizes  qualitative  changes  in  processes  to  ensure  effective 
implementation rather than a mere focus on conditionalities that do not yield clear results on the 
ground.  Accordingly,  conditions  were  formulated  with  increased  focus on  outcome  to  allow  for 
greater flexibility in actions to achieve compliance. 
 
83. 
Third, FMRIP recognizes the importance of providing predictable program support over

86. 
The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $200,000,000  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  to  help  finance  subprogram  1  of  the  FMRIP.  The  loan  will  have  a  15-year  term, 
including  a  grace  period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  and  a  commitment  charge  of 
0.75%  per  annum.  ADB’s  Board  has  waived  the  front-end  fee  of  1.00%  for  loans  approved 
before 30 June 2007. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to 
borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  on  the  basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions, 
and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in 
reliance  on  any  communication  or  advice  from  ADB.  The  Government  envisages  a  loan  of 
$200,000,000 will be needed to finance subprogram 2. The loan for subprogram 1, expected to 
be utilized over 18 months from December 2006 to June 2008, will be released in one tranche 
upon  meeting  the  conditions  of  the  policy  matrix  and  upon  loan  effectiveness.  Prior  to  the 
processing  of  subprogram  2,  the  Government  will  have  to  demonstrate  satisfactory  progress 
with program implementation under subprogram 1. 
 
The size of the proposed loan is based on (i) the importance of the sector to reinvigorate 
87. 
growth,  and  (ii)  the  weight  of  the  proposed  reforms  over  the  medium  term.  The  political  costs 
involved in implementing the reforms are considerable. The economic benefits greatly outweigh 
the costs yet only the costs immediately manifest, while the benefits take time to fully emerge. 
Currently vested interests benefit from weak enforcement of securities and insurance subsector 
regulation;  regulatory  arbitrage;  risky  but  profitable  insurance  business;  and  the  absence  of 
adequate  risk-management,  supervision,  and  transparency  in  the  areas  of  securities  trading. 
The  cost  of  not  (or  delay  in)  implementing  the  reforms  normally  associated  with  such  delays, 
would  be  substantially  higher  for  the  economy  than  adjustment  costs.  Market  forces  need  an 
effective and transparent regulatory framework. In the absence of timely reforms, the financial 
sector  will  continue  to  be  ineffective  in  intermediating  resources  for  productive  investment, 
financial institutions will remain vulnerable to systemic risks, and investors will be vulnerable to 
fraud and misconduct. 
 
88. 
In  addition,  the  direct  adjustment  costs  comprise  the  following  components:  (i)  the 
estimated  shortfall  in  the  DIF  (with  currently  more  than  440  banks  under  receivership  and  the 
risk of many more needing assistance, the DIF is far short of the estimated amount of about $1 
billion needed in relation to the risks in the banking system); (ii) the foregone revenues resulting 
from the resolution of NPAs under the SPV Act; and (iii) improvements needed to the securities 
market infrastructure and institutional capacity as detailed in para. 89. The fiscal benefits under 
the  SPV  Act  include  exemption  from  payment  of  documentary  stamp  tax,  capital  gains  tax, 
creditable  withholding  tax,  and  value-added  tax  or  gross  receipts  tax.  Transactions  qualified 
under the SPV Act are entitled to various fee reductions such as mortgage and land registration,

from the SPV transactions from their taxable gross income for up to 10 years. With an estimated 
P100 billion of NPAs to be disposed of under the provisions of the SPV Act, the loss in revenues 
due to the various incentives provided is estimated at $100 million.

V. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
97. 
The objective of the TA for Strengthening Regulation and Governance is to support the 
Insurance Commission, PDIC, and SEC in preparing and implementing key policy reforms. TA 
assistance  for  the  Insurance  Commission  will  include  (i)  development  of  practices  and 
methodologies to implement risk-based supervision and related capacity building; (ii) support for 
reorganization by preparing the human resource component including staffing, skills base, and 
job  descriptions;  (iii)  development  of  a  strategy  to  fully  implement  IAIS  28  core  principles; 
(iv) development of analytical processes and manuals to support upgrading of information and 
communication  technology,  including  introduction  of  electronic  filing  and  analysis;  and  (v) 
development of a road map for insurance subsector development.  
 
98. 
The  TA  will  assist  PDIC  in  (i)  identifying  legal  amendments  to  revise  its  resolution 
methods and introducing additional instruments for more effective resolution of failed banks; (ii) 
formulating  guidelines  for  provision  of  financial  assistance  to  ailing  banks;  (iii)  developing  a 
framework for efficient disposal of assets including asset valuation, management, and disposal; 
and  (iv)  preparing  a  contingency  plan  for  dealing  with  the  failure  of  a  large  bank  and/or  a 
number of banks in succession.  
 
99. 
The assistance to SEC will include (i) building the capacity of SEC staff for regulating the 
secondary  trading  of  fixed-income  securities;  (ii)  developing  an  action  plan  for  moving  to  a 
dematerialized  environment  including  preparation  of  rules  for  scripless  securities;  (iii)  building 
the  capacity  of  staff  to  more  effectively  monitor  compliance  with  IAS  39;  (iv)  assisting  SEC  in 
standardizing  books  and  records  requirements  of  investment  houses  and  other  NBFIs  to  help 
SEC  in  turn  standardize  audit  procedures;  and  (v)  enhancing  the  supervisory  framework  to 
ensure prompt public disclosure of material information by public companies and their officers, 
directors, and principal shareholders, with respect to beneficial ownership. 
 
100.  Additional  assistance  is  being  provided  under  ongoing  TA:  Support  for  Nonbank 
Financial  Governance  II23 and  Strengthening  Governance  of  Securities  Trading  Markets24 for 
SEC to (i) evaluate compliance with the risk-based capital for brokerage firms, (ii) evaluate the 
effectiveness  of  PSE’s  new  SRO  structure  in  addressing  conflict  of  interest  concerns  and  its 
capacity  to  effectively  perform  its  surveillance  and  audit  functions,  and  (iii)  develop  a  public 
awareness  campaign  on  the  role  of  the  new  fixed-income  exchange  in  promoting  greater 
transparency  in  the  pricing  of  fixed-income  securities  to  deepen  and  improve  liquidity  in  the 
secondary market. All these measures are expected to support SEC and other key stakeholders 
in fulfilling the policy actions under subprograms 1 and 2.

VI. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Benefits 

Social and Environmental Safeguards 

A. 
 
102.  Economic  growth  and  job  creation  are  the  cornerstones  of  the  MTPDP.  The  program 
supports  the  Government’s  development  agenda  and  the  development  of  a  more  efficient 
financial sector that encourages increased personal savings and the direction of those savings 
into  appropriate,  private  sector  investments.  The  FMRIP  will  lead  to  enhanced  stability  in  the 
financial  system,  strengthened  governance  in  the  nonbank  financial  subsector,  and  improved 
efficiency  in  the  securities  market  that  will  all  contribute  to  a  more  conducive  environment  for 
continued financial market development. The policies supported by the FMRIP are expected to 
contribute to enhanced investor confidence, and stimulate domestic and foreign investments. 
 
103.  The FMRIP will boost competition in the financial sector and facilitate growth of financial 
intermediaries, while improving the efficiency of capital markets and improving the allocation of 
resources in the economy. Financial intermediaries will be enabled to develop a wider range of 
attractive financial products for consumers, which will improve the efficiency of intermediation by 
channeling greater savings into the financial system. A stronger, more  resilient and diversified 
financial  sector  will  support  higher  investments  and  productivity  growth  through  private  sector 
development.  Together  with  broader  economic  reforms  in  the  Philippines,  the  reform  of  the 
financial sector will contribute to higher growth. This will indirectly contribute to poverty reduction 
through  expected  job  creation,  and  also  from  the  fiscal  space  created  by  enhanced  revenues 
that will allow increased social spending and public investments.  
 
B. 
 
104.  The  FMRIP  will  not  entail  any  involuntary  resettlement  or  have  a  negative  impact  on 
indigenous  people  or  the  environment.  The  FMRIP  is  classified  as  category  C  for  involuntary 
resettlement, impact on indigenous people, and environmental impact. The FMRIP is a general 
intervention aimed at supporting sustainable economic growth and in that respect is expected to 
have an indirect positive effect on poverty reduction. Appendix 8 contains the summary poverty 
and social impact analysis and Appendix 9 the environmental impact analysis. 
 
C. 
 
105. 
Implementation of the FMRIP faces a number of key risks, for which mitigating measures 
have  been  put  in  place,  as  appropriate.  However  subprogram  1  will  face  some  risks.  First, 
political instability could negatively impact the pace of reform and the macroeconomy. However, 
while  the  significant  political  disturbances  during  2005  had  an  impact  on  spreads  on 
international bonds, domestically the reforms moved ahead, albeit with a delay.  
 
106.  Second,  exogenous  shocks  to  the economy  will  adversely  affect  growth  prospects  and 
threaten macroeconomic stability. That could in turn lead to lower confidence among consumers 
and  business,  reduce  demand  for  finance,  and  increase  the  focus  on  safe  assets,  i.e.,  a 
preference for savings deposits for consumers and investments in government debt rather than 
lending for banks. Global growth prospects remain positive. A slowdown in United States growth 
appears to be offset by the recovery in Japan and stronger growth in Europe. Strong growth in 
Asia  bodes  well  for  export  demand  with  intraregional  trade  rising.  The  FMRIP,  in  conjunction 
with additional reform programs financed by ADB and the Development Policy Support Program, 

Risks  

  

 

29 

proposed with joint financing with the World Bank, contributes to sustaining the economy on an 
enhanced growth path while mitigating the risks of macroeconomic instability. The FMRIP also 
helps  to  cushion  the  economy  from  its  remaining  exposure  to  adverse  shocks  through  its 
provision of significant financial resources on favorable terms. 
 
107.  The third risk would be delays in pursuing financial sector reforms in line with the CMDP 
and the MTPDP. The momentum in financial sector reforms should not be lost while temporary 
setbacks may be experienced over the course of the FMRIP as the alternative of not pursuing 
reforms  would  have  a  negative  effect  on  the  investment  climate,  and  consumer  and  investor 
confidence.  However,  this  risk  is  considered  small  as  the  regulatory  agencies  are  strongly 
committed to reform. 
 
108.  A fourth risk is that some reforms will be undertaken without sufficient consideration of 
appropriate  sequencing  with  the  result  that  risks  are  transferred  to  institutions  and  markets 
before they are able to acquire adequate capacity for risk management. The FMRIP mitigates 
this risk by providing program support and TA that strengthen the capacity of policy makers and 
regulators  to  address  these  concerns.  These  risks  are  further  mitigated  by  a  consultative 
approach that is grounded in stakeholder discussions with the private sector, government, and 
key  international  partners  such  as  the  International  Monetary  Fund,  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development, World Bank, and others.  
 
109.  Finally, serious concerns relate to inadequate standards of governance and incidence of 
corruption in the Philippines. The Government's MTPDP views graft and corruption as threats to 
the  sustained  growth  and  development  of  the  country.  As  such  the  consensus  is  strong  that 
good governance and measures to address corruption are needed for a successful partnership 
to  reduce  poverty  in  the  Philippines.  In  view  of  this,  support  projects  are  to  be  designed  to 
enhance governance and reduce opportunities for corruption. The thrust will be to institute and 
implement  regulatory  and  legal  reforms  by  promoting  the  independence  of  the  regulator,  and 
separate  operator  and  regulator  functions.  Moreover,  institutional  reforms  will  aim  to  ensure 
transparency  and  accountability;  and  to  mitigate,  if  not  eradicate,  administrative  impropriety  of 
respective  government  agencies.  This  will  be  reinforced  by  strengthening  consolidated 
supervision  mechanisms  via  closer  cooperation  and  coordination  among  financial  services 
regulatory agencies. For instance, the Financial Sector Forum (para. 18) provides a platform for 
exchanging information and ideas, and coordinating regulatory and supervisory activities of the 
four member agencies. BSP has been able to keep pace with innovations in regulation and has 
been diligent in its implementation of international best practices in regulation. SEC is a much 
stronger  organization,  having  undertaken  various  reforms  since  1998  under  the  SRC.  SEC  is 
primarily responsible for implementing the CMDP. Successful implementation of the CMDP with 
the support of the FMRIP should strengthen the capacity and authority of SEC in regulating and 
ensuring good governance in the securities market. The amendment of the Insurance Code and 
the  reorganization  of  the  Insurance  Commission  will  lead  to  an  improved  legal  and  regulatory 
framework for the insurance industry and enhance governance and supervision in the insurance 
subsector.

SECTOR ANALYSIS  

 
Philippine  Financial  Structure  and  Regional  Comparison.1 The  deepening  of  the 
1. 
financial sector in the Philippines is marginal compared with other countries in the region. The 
market capitalization of Asian equity, on average, has trebled since 1997 and the capitalization 
as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) in Southeast Asian economies such as Hong 
Kong, China; Singapore; or Malaysia compares favorably to countries such as the United States, 
United  Kingdom,  or  Germany.  However,  the  same  does  not  apply  to  the  Philippines,  People’s 
Republic  of  China,  and  Indonesia  (Table  A2.1).  The  financial  system  in  terms  of  composition 
and growth has not progressed in comparison to the regional average. In 2005 in the Philippines, 
banking assets as a percentage of GDP were 63.2, equity market capitalization 40.4, and bonds 
outstanding  36.7,  much  lower  when  compared  with  Malaysia;  Republic  of  Korea;  Hong  Kong, 
China; and Singapore. Again, corporate bonds comprised a very small percentage of the overall 
bonds outstanding in these economies, including the Philippines.

2. 
The  Philippines  ranks  lowest  in  the  region  (other  than  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic and Cambodia) in terms of investment as a share of GDP (%). Philippines investment 
to GDP ratio of 17% as of 2004 is lower compared with other economies in the region. 
  
3. 
Composition of the Financial System and Bank Dominance. The various institutions 
that constitute the Philippine financial system can be broadly classified as banks and nonbank 
financial institutions (NBFIs). The banking subsector can be further divided into universal banks 
(expanded commercial banks), commercial banks, rural banks, and thrift banks, which include 
savings  and  mortgage  banks,  stock  savings  and  loans  associations,  and  private  development 
banks.  The  Bangko  Sentral  ng  Pilipinas  (BSP)  is  the  central  bank.  NBFIs  include  insurance 
companies,  financing  companies,  investment  houses,  securities  brokers  and  dealers,  lending 
investors, fund managers, pension funds, and non-stock-savings and loan associations. Taken 
as  a  whole,  the  relative  importance  of  the  financial  system  barely  changed  over  the  past  two 
decades. In 1980, the ratio of the financial system’s total assets to gross national product was 
101.6% and is hardy different in 2005. Historically, nonbanks accounted for 18% of the financial

4. 
Philippines  Banking  System. The banking system comprises a small number of large 
banks  and  a  large  number  of  thrift  and  rural  banks.  Recently  the  Philippines  consolidated  the 
banking system, reducing the number of commercial banks from 51 in 1997 to 24 in 2005. The 
majority of the banking system is privately owned with foreign ownership limited to about 9% in 
the  top  10  banks.  The  percentage  of  nonperforming  loans  has  been  gradually  declining  from 
about 16.7% in 2002 to about 7.36% at end of May 2006. The creation of the special purpose 
vehicle framework resulted in the resolution of nonperforming loans and as a result in April 2006 
the  special  purpose  vehicle  law  was  extended  for  2  more  years  to  support  continued 
strengthening of the banks’ balance sheets. 
 
5. 
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the Regulator. The rehabilitation and creation of a strong 
and independent central monetary authority (BSP) charged with supervising financial institutions 
is the most important landmark in the Philippine financial sector during the last decade. The type 
of  supervision  has  moved  from  transaction-based  to  process,  based  on  a  risk  management 
systems approach. BSP is considered to be independent from the central Government and its 
income-generating activities reinforce this perception. Since BSP is able to earn its own income, 
it is not very dependent on the Government for its funding, unlike the Securities and Exchange 
Commission (SEC). Furthermore, the compensation or pay scales of BSP employees are much 
more  relative  to  regular  government  employees,  thereby  allowing  them  to  hire  highly  qualified 
staff  for  its  operations.  BSP  is  also  able  to  allocate  more  resources  for  training,  thereby 
enhancing its regulatory capabilities. BSP has kept pace with innovations in regulation and been 
diligent in its implementation of international best practices in regulation. 
 
Overreliance  on  the  banking  industry  clearly  demonstrates  the  need  for  alternative 
6. 
channels  of  financial  intermediation  through  the  capital  market  to  deepen  the  financial  sector 
and diversify risks in the system. 
 
Capital Markets Regulator, Securities and Exchange Commission. SEC, established 
7. 
in 1936, regulates the capital market, licenses and supervises self-regulatory organizations, and 
is  responsible  for  company  registration  and  the  conduct  of  market  participants.  SEC  is 
responsible to the secretary of finance and funded under the Department of Finance budget. Its 
role  in  company  registration  brings  in  significant  revenue,  of  which  SEC  is  allowed  to  retain  a 
small  proportion.  SEC  draws  its  authority  from  the  Securities  Registration  Code  (SRC)  (July 
2000). The code focuses on four core functions: (i) capital market development and regulation, 

 

 38 

Appendix 2 

(ii) company registration and monitoring, (iii) enforcement, and (iv) support services. SEC is led 
by  a  chairperson  and  four  other  commissioners  and  has  350  staff.  SEC  is  a  much  stronger 
organization than it was in 1998 due to the reforms carried out under the SRC. Though SEC is 
now  more  committed  to  regulating  the  capital  markets,  lack  of  funds  and  authority  restricts  its 
scope  in  providing  leadership  to  the  market.  The  imbalance  between  BSP  and  SEC  in  the 
regulatory structure reflects the relative underfunding of SEC when compared with BSP.  
 
8. 
The  Second  Nonbank  Financial  Governance  Program  supported  the  development  of 
training  programs,  development  and  utilization  of  information  technology,  and  review  and 
revision of inspection procedures to enhance the SEC’s supervisory and surveillance capability. 
SEC issued regulations for the adoption of international accounting standards by all companies 
registered  with  SEC  and  also  began  accrediting  auditors  and  imposing  new  reporting 
requirements on auditors. SEC issued and, since December 2005, has been implementing risk-
based  capital  adequacy  standards  for  brokerage  firms.  SEC  is  primarily  responsible  for 
implementing the Capital Market Development Plan; successful implementation with the support 
of  the  Financial  Market  Intermediation  and  Regulation  Program  (FMRIP)  should  facilitate 
development  of  the  nonbank  financial  sector  and  enhance  SEC’s  capacity  and  authority  in 
regulating and developing the securities market. 
 
A. 
 

Market Infrastructure  

Philippine Stock Exchange  

1. 
 
9. 
The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) is the country’s only licensed exchange (licensed 
by  SEC).  PSE  is  a  much  improved  organization  from  what  it  was  in  1998.  It  demonstrates 
greater commitment to its regulatory responsibilities although the transfer of ownership from the 
membership  as  prescribed  in  the  SRC  is  still  pending.  PSE  became  a  demutualized  public 
company in 2001, separating ownership and trading rights. Previous broker members retained 
their trading rights even if they sold their shares. The SRC mandates the demutualization and 
limits brokers’ shareholdings to 20%. That has yet to be reached. Thus the brokers still exercise 
much  influence  in  PSE  decision  making.  PSE  operates  a  conventional  public  electronic  order 
book. The country has one national depository for equities, the Philippines Central Depository; 
one clearing agent system run by PSE, the Securities Clearing Corporation of the Philippines; 
and  two  settlement  banks  that  share  the  cash  transmission  associated  with  trading.  PSE  has 
two trading floors for historical reasons although trading is conducted electronically, with direct 
input  of  orders  from  the  floor  permitted.  Trading  hours  are  09.30  to  12:00  with  a  10-minute 
extension. Trading is almost exclusively in equities.  
 
10. 
Three  boards  list  237  companies.  The  first  board  is  for  companies  with  a  minimum 
capital of P400 million, have been in operation for 3 full fiscal years immediately prior to listing, 
with a cumulative pretax profit of at least P50 million and a minimum pretax profit of P10 million 
for  each  of  the  3  years.  A  minimum  of  1,000  stockholders  is  required.  The  second  board 
comprises  companies  with  minimum  authorized  capital  of  P100  million.  No  track  record  is 
required,  but  applicants  must  demonstrate  superior  growth  and  have  a  minimum  of  500 
stockholders. The third board, the Small and Medium Enterprises Board is for companies with 
capitalization  of  between  P20  million  and  P100  million,  a  1-year  track  record,  and  50 
stockholders at the time of listing. A minimum public float rule of 10%–30% was suspended until 
the end of 2005. A board for trading of retail bonds was closed after 3 years due to thin trading.  
 
PSE trading was lackluster in the years following the Asian crisis but picked up in 2004 
11. 
and 2005. The index grew by 26.4% in 2004 and 39.1% in 2005. Market capitalization remains 
low by international and regional comparison at 41% of GDP equivalent. PSE has 123 member-

 

  

Appendix 2 

39 

brokers; 9 are foreign. The foreign brokers account for 50% of trading volumes. As of the end of 
2004, about 42% of the stock market was not accessible to foreign investors. In addition, 40% of 
the shares are closely held leaving a very small float freely available to would-be investors and 
thereby affecting the liquidity and efficiency of the stock market. Low liquidity and efficiency in 
the  securities  markets  is  again  demonstrated  by  the  low  institutional  investor  base  in  the 
Philippines, People’s Republic of China, and Indonesia, among the lowest in the region. Among 
the  developing  markets  in  the  region,  PSE  shows  the  least  success  in  growing  its  listed 
companies—its  stock  of  tradable  assets.  PSE  has  initiated  moves  to  strengthen  investor 
protection  and  confidence  through  considerable  strides  to  improve  its  governance  structure.  It 
has  had  less  success  in  broadening  PSE  ownership.  The  absence  of  public  information  on 
ordinary  shares  makes  comment  on  the  relative  importance  of  different  classes  of  investors 
difficult (Table A2.3). 
 
12. 
Few  Philippine  companies  and  no  locally  owned  finance  company  have  any  significant 
operations  outside  the  country.  The  strategic  thrust  of  most  companies  is  to  gain  a  dominant 
share in their local market. A limited number of foreign entities have established joint ventures; 
more have invested in portfolio investments.

2. 

Philippine Dealing and Exchange Corporation  

 
15. 
The  Bankers  Association  of  the  Philippines  launched  an  initiative  to  set  up  a  fixed-
income  exchange  for  trading  of  debt  securities  to  provide  an  efficient  market  place  for  price 
discovery  and  electronic  trading.  The  Philippine  Dealing  System  owns  three  corporations:  (i) 
Philippine Dealing and Exchange Corporation (PDEx),  a trading system for debt securities: (ii) 
Philippine Securities Settlement Corporation for clearing and settlement of trades completed at 
PDEx;  and  (iii)  Philippine  Depository  and  Trust  Corporation,  the  repository  for  securities  on 
behalf  of  public  investors.  PDEx  will  (i)  facilitate  migration  from  over-the-counter  trading  to 
electronic  trading  to  achieve  transparency  and  efficient  price  discovery,  (ii)  ensure  proper 
delivery  of  securities  to  the  buyer  or  the  buyer’s  custodian,  and  (iii)  help  institutionalize  the 
system with third party custodians. PDEx began operations in March 2005; total trading in 2005 
was P437.85 billion, with a daily average turnover of P2.19 billion.  
 
B. 
 

Financial Intermediaries 

1. 

Investment Houses 

 
16. 
The 33 investment houses (investment banks in the Philippines including 6 with quasi-
banking  licenses)  are  governed  by  the  Investment  Houses  Law  (from  1973  and  revised  rules 
from 2002). They underwrite securities, provide fee-based services, and act as intermediaries in 
the  short  end  of  the  money  market.  Investment  houses  with  a  quasi-banking  license  can  also 
provide medium- and long-term loans to corporations. BSP no longer issues license for quasi-
banking  and,  to  consolidate  the  industry,  SEC  has  suspended  licenses  for  investment  houses 
without  quasi-banking  licenses.  Many  investment  houses  are  owned  by  universal  banks.  The 
investment houses without quasi-banking licenses must have a minimum paid-in capital of P300 
million. They cannot undertake underwriting commitments for amounts exceeding 20 times their 
net worth, or charge underwriting fees exceeding 5% of the funds they generate for an issue.   
 

2. 

Investment Companies  

 
17. 
Investment  companies  or  mutual  funds  were  introduced  in  1957;  the  Investment 
Company Act to govern them followed in 1960. Early development of mutual funds was patchy 
with few investment opportunities. The initial lack of regulation also contributed to scandals and 
disappointed  investors.  No  new  funds  were  registered  with  SEC  between  1972  and  1990; 

 

 42 

Appendix 2 

instead  investors  chose  to  invest  in  pre-need  products  and  common  trust  funds  operated  by 
banks. The number of mutual funds has increased by more than 50% since 2003; the net asset 
value of mutual funds has almost doubled along with mutual fund sales and number of mutual 
fund  accounts.  However,  the  size  of  this  subsector  is  still  small  compared  with  the  size  of 
common  trust  funds  (a  comparable  bank  product  in  the  Philippines)  or  with  other  regional 
mutual  fund  markets.2 A  closed-end  fund  offers  a  fixed  number  of  shares  whereas  open-end 
funds continually offer new shares to the investing public. The minimum required capital is P50 
million.  Three  companies  dominate.  The  total  assets  of  the  industry  at  the  end  of  2004 
amounted  to  P29.4  billion.  Investment  companies  are  not  very  active  on  the  stock  exchange, 
accounting for less than 2% of money invested in PSE.  
 
18. 
The  investing  public  lacks  information  about  mutual  funds,  what  they  are,  and  the 
benefits and risks of investing in funds. SEC has noted this general need for investor education.  
 
19. 
SEC has been drafting revisions to the Investment Company Act since the mid-1990s It 
advocates revisions that will (i) call for better disclosure rules, (ii) require registration with SEC 
for  all  collective  investment  schemes,  (iii)  make  licensing  of  investment  advisers  by  SEC 
mandatory,  (iv)  clarify  separation  of  funds  between  the  corporation  and  invested  funds,  (v) 
require independent directors on the board, and (vi) allow foreigners to become board members. 
SEC  plans  to  introduce  risk-based  capital  provisions  in  implementing  regulation.  These 
amendments  would  meet  the  International  Organization  of  Securities  Commissions  (IOSCO) 
principles 16–20 for collective investment schemes.    

 
3. 

Pre-Need Companies  

 
20. 
Pre-need policies are essentially savings schemes to provide for major life-time events, 
e.g.,  weddings  and  education.  They  are  split  for  regulatory  purposes  into  three  groups: 
education,  life,  and  pension.  Pre-need  companies  have  tended  to  offer  unachievable 
guaranteed returns and been forced to unilaterally alter the terms of payments. Essentially they 
became actuarially insolvent and were forced to reduce their commitments. The pre-need firms’ 
trust  fund  investments  reached  P66.37  billion  as  of  30  June  2004  (the  latest  available  data). 
Despite  the  industry’s  rapid  growth  and  recent  financial  difficulty,  no  law  specifically  governs 
pre-need  companies.  Recently,  the  basic  sales  practices  and  governance  of  the  pre-need 
industry have been questioned.  
 
21. 
Currently,  SEC  licenses  and  regulates  pre-need  companies,  but  SEC’s  performance  in 
regulating the funds and enforcing these regulations has been lacking. SEC is responsible for 
defining  the  investor  protection  scheme  as  well  as  interpreting  this  scheme.  Under  the  SRC, 
SEC officials and staff, when challenged for taking specific actions in their official capacity, are 
required  to  demonstrate  that  they  acted  with  “extraordinary  diligence”  to  avoid  liability  for 
enforcing  substantive  requirements  that  they  might  have  been  responsible  for  developing. 
Responsible  staff  and  officials  are  therefore  reluctant  to  take  enforcement  actions  that  may 
invite  a  legal  challenge.  Instead,  SEC  appears  to  use  its  power  to  deny  renewal  of  annual 
registration  to  dealers  selling  pre-need  plans  of  pre-need  companies  experiencing  financial 
difficulties  (such  as  trust  fund  deficiencies  and  related  impairment  of  capital).  As  a  result,  the 
number of pre-need plan companies with licenses to sell pre-need plans has declined from 43 in 
2003  to  29  in  2006.  A  comprehensive  overhaul  of  the  regulatory  framework  is  needed  to

The 

address current liquidity problems experienced by several large pre-need plan companies. A bill 
to establish a pre-need code has been before Congress for the last 5 years. It also proposes the 
transfer of regulatory authority from SEC to the Insurance Commission.  
 
22.  More sustainable reforms for both the pre-need and mutual fund sectors are dependent 
on  the  enactment  of  a  comprehensive  regulatory  framework,  including  legislation.  Although 
relevant  bills  were  submitted  by  the  executive  branch  to  Congress,  technical  working  groups 
have  been  organized  to  discuss  the  bills,  and public  hearings  on  the bills  have  taken  place,  it 
appears  that  neither  adoption  of  a  new  pre-need  code  nor  amendment  of  the  Investment 
Company Act is a Congressional priority. 
 
 
 
23. 
Financing  companies  are  governed  by  the  Financing  Company  Act  of  1978.  They 
engage in leasing and consumer finance, but derive about 25% of their income from securities 
trading.  Total  assets  of  the  319  financing  companies  registered  with  the  SEC  amounted  to 
P55.6 billion at the end of 2004.  
 
C. 

Financing Companies 

4. 

the  Regulator.  The 

Insurance  Commission, 

Insurance  Commission,  a 
24. 
government agency under the Department of Finance, supervises and regulates the operations 
of  life  and  nonlife  companies,  mutual  benefit  associations,  and  trusts  for  charitable  uses.  It 
issues  licenses  to  insurance  agents,  general  agents,  resident  agents,  underwriters,  brokers, 
adjusters,  and  actuaries;  and  has  the  authority  to  suspend  or  revoke  such  licenses.  The 
commission  currently  has  216  staff.  The  regulatory  and  supervisory  capacity  of  the  Insurance 
Commission needs to be strengthened, and the Insurance Code amended to improve the legal 
and  regulatory  framework  for  the  insurance  industry.  To  achieve  effective  supervision,  the 
Insurance Commission needs to be reorganized.  
 
25. 
Insurance  Companies.  The  country  has  32  life  insurance  companies  and  104  nonlife 
insurance companies. The low capital requirement of P50 million may explain the large number 
of companies as the penetration rate is low with an estimated less than 17% of the population 
having insurance policies. Despite the large number of companies, the life insurance premium 
collected  was  only  1.27%–1.30%  of  GDP  during  2002–2004.  Insurance  penetration  as  a 
percentage of GDP in the Philippines is among the lowest in the region (Table A2.6). Similarly, 
the  density  ratio,  measured  as  the  premium  per  capita  is  equally  low  with  good  potential  for 
growth  that  would  depend  on  the  quality  of  products  and  services  offered  and  distribution 
channels. The sector was liberalized in 1994 allowing foreign firms to own 100% equity stakes 
in insurers and to enter the market by either a local joint venture or setting up a local subsidiary 
or branch. Three foreign companies are active: Philippine American Life and General Insurance 
(local  subsidiary  of  American  International  Group),  SunLife  (Canada),  and  Manulife  (Canada). 
Philippine American Life dominates the market with 28% share followed by SunLife with 17%. 
The five largest life insurance companies have a market share in terms of assets of about 83%. 
The  three  foreign  companies  accounted  for  50%  of  total  premium  income  in  2004.  The  life 
insurance  companies  are  major  investors  in  equities,  government  securities,  corporate  debt, 
and  real  estate.  The  nonlife  insurance  companies  are  mostly  small  family-owned  companies; 
growth in premiums has been low. The country has two domestic reinsurance companies.

D. 
 
Insurance 
26. 
Corporation (PDIC) was established in 1963 by Republic Act 3591, amended in 2004. The new 
law  has  enhanced  the  authority  of  PDIC  in  its  role  of  deposit  insurer  and  strengthens  the 
mechanisms  to  maintain  systemic  stability  in  the  financial  system.  PDIC  has  three  core 
functions: (i) insurer of bank deposits, (ii) receiver/liquidator of closed banks, and (iii) coregulator 
of  banks  in  collaboration  with  BSP.  Current  deposit  insurance  coverage  is  P250,000.  The 
proportion of deposit covered by the insurance is about 25% of total deposits in terms of value 
but 95% of total accounts (Table A2.7). This probably is a consequence of the low savings rate 
in  the  country.  PDIC  oversees  the  Deposit  Insurance  Fund,  which  consists  of  the  Permanent 
Insurance Fund, assessment collections, reserves for insurance and financial assistance losses, 

Insurance  Corporation.  The  Philippine  Deposit 

 

  

Appendix 2 

45 

and  retained  earnings.  The  Deposit  Insurance  Fund  stands  at  P47.2  billion  compared  with  an 
estimated required P90 billion given the risks in the system.  
 
27. 
The Monetary Board can close a bank and place it in receivership in cases of (i) inability 
to  meet  depositor  demands,  (ii)  insolvency,  (iii)  violation  of  cease-and-desist  order,  or 
(iv) continued operations that are likely to lead to losses for depositors and creditors. PDIC then 
becomes the receiver and must within 60 days recommend to the Monetary Board whether to 
rehabilitate or liquidate a failed bank. Rehabilitation is done if new investors are available and if 
it  represents  a  least-cost  solution  compared  with  closure  and  liquidation.  Financial  assistance 
takes  the  form  of  asset  purchases,  direct  loans,  or  assumption  of  liabilities.  Such  assistance 
must meet a least-cost test.

28. 
During  1970–1998,  339  banks  were  closed,  of  which  six  were  commercial  banks,  44 
thrift banks, and 289 rural banks. The closed banks had cumulative deposit liabilities of P5,657 
million that was met by PDIC.3 One of the impediments that inhibit PDIC from more effectively 
monitoring banks and receive timely information is the country’s law of secrecy of deposits The 
increase in maximum insurance cover has not been matched with a corresponding increase in 
the assessment rate. This may impact PDIC’s capability to meet insurance claims in the future. 
PDIC needs to revise its resolution methods and identify additional instruments and options to 
address  bank  failures,  asset  disposal  techniques,  and  strengthen  the  framework  for  selecting 
strategic investors. This will be supported through the FMRIP. 
 
Unlike the banking industry, the securities and insurance industries have not seen major 
29. 
revisions  in  their  regulatory  structure  for  some  time  despite  many  changes  in  the  competitive 
environment  and  products  being  offered.  Enactment  of  the  SRC,  somewhat  earlier  in  2000, 
mandated  a  comprehensive  revision  of  the  Philippine  securities  laws  to  ensure  a  modern 
framework  for  the  securities  industry.  However,  important  legislation  such  as  that  proposed  to 
reintroduce a pre-need plan code, corporate recovery act, and the revised Investment Company 
Act,  which  are  still  pending  before  Congress,  needs  to  be  taken  up  in  earnest  to  reduce 
unevenness  in  the  regulatory  framework  between  the  bank  and  nonbank  subsectors.  The 
Capital Market Development Plan implemented with FMRIP support will aim to address most of 
these issues.

Development Policy Letter  

 
 
 
31 October 2006 
 
Mr. Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
Asian Development Bank 
 
PHILIPPINES: FINANCIAL MARKET INTERMEDIATION AND REGULATION PROGRAM 
 
Dear Mr. President, 
 

Let  me  thank  you  for  the  continuing  support  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  your 
own keen interest in promoting economic growth of the Philippines. Given the critical role of the 
financial  sector  in  the  growth  process,  the  development  agenda  of  the  Government  of  the 
Philippines prioritizes the need to strengthen the investment climate by promoting development 
of  a  more  efficient  financial  sector  that  can  finance  profitable  private  investment  projects  at 
lower cost and risk than at present.  

 
To  support  the  implementation  of  these  policy  goals,  the  Government  is  focusing  on 
strengthening  macroeconomic  management.  While  the  Government’s  fiscal  consolidation 
program includes a wide range of initiatives, the centerpiece comprises broadening the tax base, 
adjusting  tax  rates,  and  strengthening  tax  administration.  Progress  on  aggregate  fiscal 
consolidation was characterized as “impressive” by development partners during the Philippine 
Development Forum (PDF) in March 2006, which also assessed the program to be broadly on 
track. The Government is committed to reduce the National Government deficit/GDP to 0.9% by 
2007. The emerging trend is better than projected in the Government’s Medium Term Philippine 
Development  Plan  2004-2010  (MTPDP),  and  the  target  for  achieving  a  balanced  budget  has 
been  advanced  from  2010  to  2008.  The  International  Monetary  Fund  in  its  mid  Post-Program 
Monitoring on the Philippines, recognized significant gains from the package of reforms pursued 
by the Government over the last two years.  
 

The MTPDP emphasizes economic growth and job creation as key to poverty reduction, 
and builds on the Government’s ten point agenda. Real GDP growth rate targets are 5.3-6.3% 
in  2005  and  expected  to  increase  to  7-8%  by  2010.  Sound  debt  and  risk  management 
complemented  by  increasing  exports  and  higher  investments  are  expected  to  drive  growth. 
While the MTPDP encompasses policies and actions in several sectors it notes the importance 
of  developing  the  financial  system  to  mobilize  domestic  savings  to  support  growth.  Further 
reforms,  in  particular  in  the  non-bank  financial  sector,  are  needed  to  achieve  effective 
intermediation.  Policy  measures  need  to  be  undertaken  to  promote  diversification  of  financial 
channels,  enhance  financial  governance  and  market  efficiency  and  reduce  systemic  risks  that 
will  contribute  to  increased  investment  confidence  and  a  stronger  investment  climate.  The 
MTPDP points out the need to undertake reforms for financial deepening and outlines the key 
reforms  to  be  undertaken  from  2004-2010.  Anchored  on  the  MTPDP  is  the  Government’s 
Capital  Market  Development  Plan  -  a  blueprint  developed  for  growth  and  expanded 
contributions to the Philippine Economy, 2005-2010 (CMDP). The Government appreciates the 
support  provided  by  ADB  in  developing  the  CMDP  under  the  Second  Nonbank  Finance  and 
Governance Program 2003. 
 

The CMDP is a medium term strategy for development of the non-bank financial sector 
and articulates a series of eleven strategic objectives that are intended to stimulate the growth, 

 

  
 

Appendix 4 

49 

efficiency  and  competitiveness  of  the  Philippine  capital  market  over  the  next  five  years.  The 
CMDP  has  been  endorsed  by  the  Government  and  the  Securities  Exchange  Commission  has 
the primary responsibility in implementing the CMDP. We expect that the structure that emerges 
from the CMDP will not only be a model for others, but one that generates a positive momentum 
extending  well  beyond  2010.  The  strategic  objectives  identified  in  the  CMDP  represent  a 
combination of economic, business, and legal/regulatory factors that will materially influence the 
Philippine  capital  market’s  vitality  as  an  engine  of  economic  growth  for  the  country.  The 
Government  acknowledges  that  the  successful  implementation  of  the  CMDP’s  objectives 
requires a strong working relationship between the responsible parties in the public and private 
sectors.  An  Action  Plan  along  with  indicative  timetable  has  been  prepared  and  the  SEC  has 
established an internal monitoring unit to track and publicly disclose progress on a regular basis 
while the DOF will oversee the interests of the national Government in the project.  
 

The Government is committed to strengthen the nonbank financial institutions as it is a 
key  element  of  our  effort  to  provide  viable  financing  for  infrastructure  development.  While  the 
CMDP  primarily  focuses  on  SEC  regulated  institutions,  the  current  and  potential  future  role  of 
the  contractual  savings  vehicles  (pension  funds,  insurance  companies)  in  terms  of  mobilizing 
personal  savings  and  channeling  a  portion  of  these  funds  towards  capital  formation  to  grow 
private  sector  enterprises  is  recognized.  The  increasing  sophistication  of  financial  markets 
carries  high  inherent  risks  that  must  be  adequately  addressed  through  strong  regulatory  and 
supervisory regimes as well as adequate risk management systems and tools. Steps have been 
initiated  to  strengthen  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  the  insurance  industry.  Further 
efforts are required to strengthen the capital base of the insurance industry and to inculcate the 
habit of savings among the local population.  
 

The  Government  looks  forward  to  ADB  support  in  its  medium  term  policy  and 
development  agenda  as  articulated  in  the  CMDP.  The  ADB  has  supported  the  Government’s 
efforts  to  develop  the  financial  sector  since  1995.  Financial  sector  reforms  build  on  a  strong 
legal and regulatory framework to support agencies in their work to supervise the market as well 
as  to  provide  a  predictable  environment  for  financial  institutions  and enterprises to  operate  in. 
Major achievements include, among others, the enactment of the Securities Regulation Code in 
2000  (supported  under  the  ADB  Capital  Market  Development  Program),  the  Special  Purpose 
Vehicle Act of 2002, and the revised charter of the Philippine Deposit Insurance Corporation in 
2004.  Furthermore,  the  stock  exchange  has  been  demutualized  and a  fixed-income  exchange 
has been established.  
 

However, strengthening of the financial sector is a continuous process and further work 
is  needed  in  the  non-bank  financial  sector  to  strengthen  the  regulatory  framework  and  the 
capacity  of  the  regulators-the  SEC  and  the  Insurance  Commission  (IC).  In  addition,  further 
reforms are needed to deepen the financial sector, facilitate savings mobilization and financial 
intermediation  through  reforms  of  the  debt  and  equity  markets.  The  Government  has  thus 
developed the Financial Market Intermediation and Regulation Program (FMRIP) which will help 
the Philippines to implement the medium term reform agenda 2005-2010. This Program will be 
implemented  with  the  assistance  of  ADB  through  a  cluster  program  comprising  of  two 
subprograms over the medium-term. This momentum is needed to develop the financial sector 
in order to benefit from integration in the regional and global capital markets over the medium 
and  long-term.  The  reform  agenda  under  Subprogram  2  in  the  cluster  will  build  on  continued 
reforms to enhance financial system stability and further financial sector reforms in line with the 
CMDP and development in other nonbank sectors. 
 

 

 50 

Appendix 4 

(i) 

To implement the reform program, the FMRIP has been structured around the following 

 
components: 
 
Enhance  financial  stability.  This  will  include  measures  to  reduce  financial 
sector  vulnerabilities  and  reduce  systemic  risks  that  are  central  to  promoting  financial  sector 
development. This will be achieved though creation of a stable financial environment conducive 
to economic growth through improved debt and risk management. Steps have been initiated to 
bring  down  the  share  of  variable  interest  rates  bonds,  altering  the  currency  composition  of 
international  debt,  and  consolidating  the  number  of  outstanding  issues.  The  aim  will  be  to 
develop an enhanced debt management strategy consistent with international best practice. To 
strengthen financial intermediation and reduce the ratio of non-performing assets in the banking 
industry, the Special Purpose Act has been extended facilitating the disposition of the banking 
system’s non-performing assets and paving the way for a continued strengthening of the banks’ 
balance sheets. To improve its capacity to contribute in the stability of the banking system, the 
Philippine  Deposit  Insurance  Corporation  (PDIC)  has  developed  an  enhanced  framework  and 
guidelines  for  provision  of  financial  assistance  to  distressed  banks.  A  study  has  been 
undertaken to determine the adequacy of the Deposit Insurance Fund in relation to the risks in 
the banking system. A trading and investment policy has been formulated also in PDIC with the 
aim  of  optimizing  returns  on  the  DIF.    PDIC  will  also  identify  necessary  legal  amendments  to 
strengthen  its  methods  and  options  for  bank  failure  resolution,  formulate  specific  guidelines  in 
the judicious provision of financial assistance to banks, develop techniques for asset valuation, 
management  and  disposal,  and  prepare  a  contingency  plan  for  a  big  bank  failure  and/or 
successive  failures.    In  addition,  to  strengthen  the  nonbank  financial  institutions  and  reduce 
financial  risks  in  the  sector  the  capital  base  of  non-bank  financial  institutions  are  being 
strengthened. Measures are also being taken for the introduction of risk based capital to ensure 
that capital is adequate in relation to risks. 
 
 
Strengthen  Nonbank  Financial  Sector  Governance.  To  guide  capital  market 
development and firmly anchor the agenda with stakeholders, the CMDP has been developed in 
a  consultative  manner,  in  tandem  with  the  MTPDP.  The  CMDP  sets  forth  11  objectives  for 
capital  market  development  and  defined  initiatives  for  Government  agencies,  key  market 
institutions,  and  other  key  stakeholders.  The  CMDP  has  been  approved  and  SEC  has  been 
tasked  with  the  responsibility  of  implementing  the  Blueprint  in  coordination  with  other  relevant 
agencies.  SEC  and  IC  have  initiated  steps  to  strengthen  accounting  and  financial  reporting  in 
line  with  international  accounting  standards.  In  this  context  insurance  companies  are  now 
required to abide by Philippine Accounting Standards and Philippine Reporting Standards. SEC 
and  IC  have  now  started  publishing  a  list  of  accredited  external  auditors  on  their  respective 
websites while SEC will participate in the International Organization of Securities Commissions 
Project  on  International  Financial  Reporting  Standards  to  promote  greater  convergence  in  the 
interpretation  of  such  standards.  To  improve  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  the 
insurance industry, the Insurance Code is being amended and will be submitted to Congress for 
approval. To achieve effective supervision the Insurance Commission is being reorganized and 
a road map will be developed for the insurance industry. To implement best practice standards 
of  insurance  regulation  the  International  Association  of  Insurance  Supervisors  28  Core 
principles  will  be  adopted  over  an  agreed  time  frame.  Amendments  to  the  SRC  Code  will  be 
submitted to the Congress to enhance the legal protection to SEC staff. The Philippine Dealing 
and  Exchange  Corporation  has  been  established  to  provide  a  centralized  platform  for  fixed-
income securities operations and its role as a self regulatory organization will be strengthened. 
Amendments to the Corporation Code will also be submitted to enhance minority shareholders 
rights and promote best principles on corporate governance. 
 

(ii)

51 

(iii) 

Improve Securities Market Efficiency. These measures include developing an 
 
efficient and liquid secondary market for government debt securities through PDEx to promote 
effective price discovery and transparency that would provide for a more efficient market and an 
active yield curve. This will also include expansion of trading to qualified investors and the retail 
trading markets, and preparation for listing and trading of private fixed income securities. Steps 
are  being  taken  to  improve  the  securities  market  infrastructure  of  electronic  trading  platforms, 
clearing, settlement and payment systems for secondary trading in fixed-income securities. To 
promote  liquidity  in  securities  market  rules  for  securities  borrowing  and  lending  have  been 
introduced in the Philippine Stock Exchange and this will also be extended to PDEx very shortly.  
 
This will be followed by rules for short selling in securities. SEC will conduct a study and prepare 
an  action  plan  to  improve  supply  and  quality  of  public  offerings  of  corporate  debt.  The 
Securitization Act of 2004 was adopted to provide a legal framework for securitized issues and 
to  enable  the  development  of  the  secondary  market  for  asset-backed  securities.  The 
implementing rules and regulations of the Act were adopted on 25 March 2005. The Corporation 
Code and the SRC Code will be amended and submitted to Congress to mandate the issuance 
of securities in dematerialized form that will improve the clearance and settlement of securities. 

 
In  addition  to  the  above  measures,  steps  are  being  taken  to  improve  the  standards  of 
governance  in  Philippines.  The  thrust  will  be  to  institute  and  implement  regulatory  and  legal 
reforms  by  promoting  the  independence  of  the  regulator,  and  separate  operator  and  regulator 
functions. Moreover, institutional reforms will aim to ensure transparency and accountability and 
to mitigate, if not eradicate, administrative impropriety of respective government agencies. This 
will  be  further  reinforced  by  strengthening  consolidated  supervision  mechanisms  via  closer 
cooperation  and  coordination  among  financial  services  regulatory  agencies.  For  instance,  the 
Financial Sector Forum established in July 2004 provides a platform for exchanging information 
and ideas, and coordinating regulatory and supervisory activities of the four member agencies 
namely, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, SEC, IC and the PDIC.

THE SECOND PROGRAM 

including  adoption  and 

implementation  of  more  effective  mechanisms 

 
1. 
The  indicative  reform  agenda  under  subprogram  2  builds  on  continued  reforms  to 
enhance financial system stability and financial sector reforms in line with the CMDP and other 
nonbank  subsectors.  Efforts  will  be  concentrated  on  implementing  reform  measures  being 
developed to strengthen debt management under DOF through an enhanced debt management 
strategy 
for 
comprehensive  debt  and  risk  management  consistent  with  international  best  practices.  Fiscal 
consolidation measures to be initiated through reforms in financial performance and monitoring 
of  the  GOCCs  are  likely  to  be  covered  under  the  proposed  Development  Policy  Support 
Program.  Emphasis  under  subprogram  2  will  also  be  on  strengthening  the  insurance  industry 
through  risk-based  supervision  of  insurance  companies.  Following  full  implementation  of  the 
RBCA rule for brokers, SEC is expected to proceed with RBCA rules for other NBFIs under its 
jurisdiction.  To  ensure  the  systemic  stability  of  the  banking  industry,  PDIC  operations  will  be 
strengthened  by  enhancing  its  resolution  methods  and  mechanisms  to  address  bank  failures, 
asset  disposal  techniques,  and  the  framework  for  selecting  strategic  investors.  Subprogram  2 
will also aim to enhance PDIC’s risk management strategy. 
 
2. 
The CMDP is the basis for the nonbank financial sector reforms targeted for completion 
by  2010.  Under  subprogram  2,  progress  with  legal  changes  is  expected  by  submitting 
amendments  to  the  SRC  and  the  Corporation  Code  to  Congress.  Progress  in  the  legislative 
process  is  anticipated  for  the  amended  Insurance  Code  submitted  under  the  first  program, 
Revised  Investment  Company  Act,  Corporate  Recovery  Act,  and  Pre-Need  Code  that  are 
pending in Congress. Should any of the draft laws already submitted to Congress be enacted, 
subprogram 2 will support the preparation of implementing rules and regulations. In addition, it 
will support the Insurance Commission in managing the transfer of supervisory responsibilities 
for pre-need schemes from SEC to the commission. The draft amendments to the Corporation 
Code, among others, will prepare for a fully scripless environment for securities, targeted as a 
goal  under  the  CMDP.  In  the  interim  SEC  and  PSE  will  issue  rules  to  promote  partial 
dematerialization  for  scripless  trading.  Additional  measures  are  required  by  the  exchanges, 
clearing and settlement corporations, and depositary corporations to develop the infrastructure 
to support scripless securities.  
 
3. 
The Philippine Payment and Settlement System is a real-time gross settlement system 
that  needs  to  incorporate  a  delivery  versus  payment  system  for  transactions  in  the  secondary 
trading of government securities executed by institutional investors, nonquasi banks, and public 
investors. The extension of this delivery  versus  payment system to cover private fixed-income 
securities and to allow participation of NBFIs will help promote a more liquid secondary market.  
 
4. 
The  rules  and  regulations  introduced  under  subprogram  1  will  be  enforced  and 
monitored  by  review  missions.  SEC  is  also  expected  to  take  the  lead  in  enhancing  corporate 
governance  by  submitting  to  Congress  the  revised  amendments  to  the  Corporation  Code 
developed  under  subprogram  1.  In  addition,  SEC  is  expected  to  develop  and  implement  a 
supervisory  framework  to  ensure  prompt  public  disclosure  of  beneficial  ownership  of  public 
companies by officers, directors, and principal shareholders, and changes therein. 
 
5. 
The  Insurance  Commission  will  move  forward  with  its  reforms  to  strengthen  the 
commission  through  its  reorganization,  increasing  information  technology  utilization  for  filing, 
analysis,  and  off-site  supervision.  In  addition,  a  road  map  for  development  of  the  insurance 
industry will be developed and implemented to provide a vision and guidance for the insurance 
subsector’s development alongside the CMDP.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR 
STRENGTHENING REGULATION AND GOVERNANCE 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
1. 
To  support  implementation  of  the  Financial  Market  Regulation  and  Intermediation 
Program (FMRIP), the Government of the Philippines asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to provide technical assistance (TA). A TA grant of $800,000 is included in the 2006 assistance 
program under ADB’s country strategy and program 2005–2007 for the Philippines.1 
 
B. 

Background and Issues 

The  FMRIP  is  to  support  the  Government’s  financial  sector  reform  agenda  and 
2. 
development of capital markets and other nonbank financial services. The immediate objectives 
are  to  (i)  strengthen  macroeconomic  stability;  (ii)  strengthen  governance,  regulation,  and 
intermediation;  (ii)  enhance  transparency  and  market  efficiency;  and  (iv)  improve  operational 
efficiency  and  reduce  financial  sector  vulnerabilities.  Growth  of  the  nonbanking  financial 
subsector,  which  represents  about  20%  of  total  financial  sector  assets,  has  been  stifled  for  a 
number  of  reasons,  including  inadequate  prudential  regulations  and  insufficient  capacity  for 
monitoring and enforcing rules. The equity and debt markets lack breadth and depth because of 
policy and regulatory distortions, lack of liquidity, and weak market infrastructure.  

3. 
Development  of  the  nonbanking  financial  subsector  is  critical  to  enhancing  domestic 
resource  mobilization  and  fostering  competition  in  the  financial  sector.  A  number  of  countries 
have  achieved  savings  growth  outside  the  banking  system  by  developing  the  nonbanking 
financial subsector. The Government of the Philippines has taken concrete steps to strengthen 
and  expand  the  roles  of  the  Insurance  Commission,  Philippine  Deposit  Insurance  Corporation 
(PDIC),  and  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  (SEC)  as  part  of  its  overall  efforts  to 
introduce  reforms  in  the  financial  sector.  The  issues  and  challenges  facing  the  sector  are 
diverse  and  well-understood,  and  although  progress  to  more  efficient  markets  and  higher 
governance  standards  has  been  made  in  recent  years,  financial  sector  development  in  the 
Philippines  still  lags  in  comparison  to  the  region.  Given  the  expected  growth  and  increasing 
complexity  of  the  finance  industry,  regulators  must  possess  the  capability  to  address  difficult 
issues and assume a wider range of responsibilities The FMRIP recognizes that the regulatory

Insurance Commission. The Insurance Commission is a government agency under the 
4. 
Department  of  Finance  (DOF),  which  supervises  and  regulates  the  operation  of  insurance 
companies,  mutual  benefit  associations,  and  charitable  trusts.  Its  mandate  is  to  (i)  promote 
growth and financial stability of insurance companies, (ii) professionalize insurance services and 
develop insurance consciousness among the general population, (iii) establish a sound national 
insurance  market,  and  (iv)  safeguard  the  rights  and  interest  of  insurers.  The  Insurance 
Commission has the authority to issue and revoke licenses to insurance agents, general agents, 
resident  agents,  underwriters,  brokers,  adjusters,  and  actuaries;  adjudicates  insurance  claims 
and complaints; and conducts examinations for insurance agents.

During  formulation  of  the  FMRIP,  governance  standards  in  the  Philippine  insurance 
5. 
industry  were  identified  as  needing  strengthening.  The  Insurance  Commission  plays  a  critical 
role  in  maintaining  confidence  and  stability  in  the  industry,  and  in  its  future  development;  it  is 
also in the midst of a major reorganization and plans to develop a road map for the development 
of the insurance subsector. Progress will depend to a large extent on the commission’s capacity 
to effectively fulfill its mandate. 
 
6. 
Philippines  Deposit  Insurance  Corporation.  PDIC,  established  in  1963  by  Republic 
Act  3591  (amended  in  2004),  has  three  core  functions:  (i)  insure  bank  deposits,  (ii) 
receive/liquidate  closed  banks,  and  (iii)  coregulate  banks  in  collaboration  with  BSP.  Current 
deposit  insurance  coverage  is  P250,000.  PDIC  oversees  the  Deposit  Insurance  Fund  (DIF), 
which  comprises  the  Permanent  Insurance  Fund,  assessment  collections,  reserves  for 
insurance  and  financial  assistance  losses,  and  retained  earnings.  The  DIF  stands  at  P47.2 
billion compared with an estimated need for P90 billion to have adequate funding in relation to 
the risks in the system.  
 
PDIC had a major reorganization in 2003, and the following year Congress ratified a bill 
7. 
amending  PDIC’s  charter,  which,  among  other  things,  raised  the  maximum  value  of  insured 
deposits to P250, 000 from P100, 000. With more than 440 banks under receivership, the newly 
streamlined  organization  must  adopt  more  efficient  resolution  methods  for  failed  banks  and 
develop an effective framework for asset disposal.  
 
8. 
Securities  Exchange  Corporation.  Established  in  1936,  SEC  derives  its  mandate, 
powers  and  broad  authority  to  regulate  and  supervise  corporations,  investment  firms,  and  the 
securities  industry  from  the  SRC,  Presidential  Decree  902-A,  Corporation  Code,  Investment 
Houses  Law,  Investment  Company  Act,  Financing  Company  Act,  and  other  statutes.  SEC 
regulates the capital market, and licenses and supervises self-regulatory organizations including 
the  Philippine  Stock  Exchange,  Philippine  Central  Depository  Inc.,  and  Securities  Clearing 
Corporation  of  the  Philippines.  SEC  also  oversees  company  registration  and  the  conduct  of 
market participants. SEC has a broad and strategic mandate to regulate the securities market. It 
is, however, subject to oversight from DOF. Its rules and decisions can be subject to challenges 
in the courts. It lacks financial autonomy, which impacts its flexibility to meet this mandate. SEC 
financing  remains  a  major  obstacle  to  effective  market  regulation  and  enforcement,  and  has 
limited  SEC’s  ability  to  modernize  its  internal  systems  and  controls,  and  to  function  as  an 
effective regulator of the securities market. 
 
SEC  has,  in  consultation  with  various  stakeholders,  developed  the  Capital  Market 
9. 
Development  Plan  with  strategic  objectives  focusing  on  major  policy,  institutional,  legal,  and 
regulatory issues during 2005–2010. 
 
10.  With all three agencies making efforts to raise standards to international levels, each will 
require  considerable  financial  and  technical  resources  to  implement  their  respective  programs 
under the reform agenda.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines: 
 
The Government of the Philippines has adopted the targets set under the Millennium Development Goals 
in addition to its Medium-Term Philippine Development Program (MTPDP) goals for growth, job creation, 
and poverty reduction. Macroeconomic stability and equitable growth is foremost in the Philippines poverty 
reduction  focus.  Stronger  public  finances  will  provide  fiscal  space  for  increased  social  expenditure  and 
investments. A strong, resilient, and more diversified financial sector will support growth and investments 
and thereby indirectly contribute to poverty reduction. A well-functioning financial sector is vital to support 
enterprise development, job creation, and in turn poverty reduction.   
B. 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Because the Financial Market Regulation and Intermediation Program is a general intervention, no specific 
poverty  analysis  was  undertaken,  as  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  poverty  assessment  was  recently 
concluded  and  provides  an  in-depth  analysis.  The  Program  is  anchored  in  the  MTPDP,  which  has  clear 
targets for poverty reduction based on overall growth targets for the economy.

ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT OF THE POLICY MATRIX 

 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
The proposed Financial Market Regulation and Intermediation Program (FMRIP) aims to 
1. 
increase  the  contribution  of  the  financial  sector  to  economic  growth  and  development  of  the 
Philippines  by  promoting  a  more  efficient  financial  sector  that  can  finance  profitable  private 
investment projects at lower cost and risk. The FMRIP is a program cluster that comprises two 
subprograms to support the Government’s financial sector reforms over the medium term, while 
allowing  for  some  flexibility  in  the  composition  of  the  reforms  for  subprogram  2.  This 
environmental  assessment  report  examines  the  environmental  impacts  of  the  policy  component  of

Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan (MTPDP), under the following headings (Table A8):
